item.title: Ideological Oppression
item.description: Any oppressive system has at its core the idea that one group is somehow better than another, and in some measure has the right to control the other group. This idea gets elaborated in many ways - more intelligent, harder working, stronger, more capable, more noble, more deserving, more advanced, chosen, normal, superior, and so on. The dominant group holds this idea about itself. And, of course, the opposite qualities are attributed to the other group - stupid, lazy, weak, incompetent, worthless, less deserving, backward, abnormal, inferior, and so on.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Institutional Oppression
item.description:
The idea that one group is better than another group and has the right to control the other gets embedded in the institutions of the society - the laws, the legal system and police practice, the education system and schools, hiring policies, public policies, housing development, media images, political power, etc.
When a woman makes two thirds of what a man makes in the same job, it is institutionalized sexism. When one out of every four African-American young men is currently in jail, on parole, or on probation, it is institutionalized racism.
When psychiatric institutions and associations 'diagnose' transgender people as having a mental disorder, it is institutionalized gender oppression and transphobia.
Institutional oppression does not have to be intentional.
For example, if a policy unintentionally reinforces and creates new inequalities between privileged and non-privileged groups.

item.title: Internalized Oppression
item.description:
The fourth way oppression works is within the groups of people who suffer the most from the mistreatment. Oppressed people internalize the ideology of inferiority, they see it reflected in the institutions, they experience disrespect interpersonally from members of the dominant group, and they eventually come to internalize the negative messages about themselves. If we have been told we are stupid, worthless, abnormal, and have been treated as if we were all our lives, then it is not surprising that we would come to believe it. This makes us feel bad.
Oppression always begins from outside the oppressed group, but by the time it gets internalized, the external oppression need hardly be felt for the damage to be done. If people from the oppressed group feel bad about themselves, and because of the nature of the system, do not have the power to direct those feelings back toward the dominant group without receiving more blows, then there are only two places to dump those feelings - on oneself and on the people in the same group. Thus, people in any target group have to struggle hard to keep from feeling heavy feelings of powerlessness or despair. They often tend to put themselves and others down, in ways that mirror the oppressive messages they have gotten all their lives. Acting out internalized oppression runs the gamut from passive powerlessness to violent aggression. It is important to understand that some of the internalized patterns of behavior originally developed to keep people alive - they had real survival value.
On the way to eliminating institutional oppression, each oppressed group has to undo the internalized beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors that stem from the oppression so that it can build unity among people in its group, support its leaders, feel proud of its history, contributions, and potential, develop the strength to challenge patterns that hold the group back, and organize itself into an effective force for social change.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Internalized Privilege
item.description: Likewise, people who benefit the most from these systems internalize privilege. Privileged people involuntarily accept stereotypes and false assumptions about oppressed groups made by dominant culture. Internalized privilege includes acceptance of a belief in the inherent inferiority of the oppressed group as well as the inherent superiority or normalcy of one’s own privileged group. Internalized privilege creates an unearned sense of entitlement in members of the privileged group, and can be expressed as a denial of the existence of oppression and as paternalism.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Interpersonal Oppression
item.description:
The idea that one group is better than another and has the right to control the other, which gets structured into institutions, gives permission and reinforcement for individual members of the dominant group to personally disrespect or mistreat individuals in the oppressed group.
Interpersonal racism is what white people do to people of color up close--the racist jokes, the stereotypes, the beatings and harassment, the threats, etc. Similarly, interpersonal sexism is what men do to women - the sexual abuse and harassment, the violence directed at women, the belittling or ignoring of women's thinking, the sexist jokes, etc.
Most people in the dominant group are not consciously oppressive. They have internalized the negative messages about other groups, and consider their attitudes towards the other group quite normal.

item.title: Labor Acknowledgement
item.description:
A labor acknowledgement is a statement that recognizes that much of the economic progress and development in a geographic area or industry resulted from the unpaid labor and forced servitude of People of Color - specifically enslaved African labor.
Labor acknowledgements are one way to 'honor and remember the violent histories and legacies of settler colonialism' and to 'collectively begin to acknowledge the historical labor that has allowed our society to get and be where it is today, then we will continue to struggle to reconcile and redress those histories and legacies.' Terah TJ Stewart
Like most modern day US institutions, Solid Ground benefits from the unaddressed legacy of stolen labor at the foundation of this nation and its vast and inequitable wealth.
We respectfully acknowledge our debt to the enslaved people, primarily of African descent, whose labor and suffering built and grew the economy and infrastructure of a nation that refused to recognize their humanity.
While the 13th Amendment to the Constitution technically ended 'slavery' in the US, we know that slavery's ongoing impacts are still felt by countless people forced - through violence, threats, and coercion - to work in the US.
We recognize our debt to exploited workers past and present whose labor was and continues to be stolen through unjust practices.
We acknowledge our collective debt to the Indigenous peoples of this land whose labor was forced and exploited, the Chinese immigrants who built railroads that allowed for westward American development, Japanese Americans whose properties and livelihoods were taken from them while incarcerated during World War II, and migrant workers from the Philippines, Mexico, and Central and South America who have worked Pacific Northwest farms and canneries.
We recognize the immigrant and American-born workers of African, Asian, and Central and South American descent whose labor remains hidden in the shadows but still contributes to the wellbeing of our collective community.
We recognize that our economy continues to rely on the exploited labor of incarcerated people, largely people of color, who earn pennies an hour while generating billions in goods and services each year. And we know there are many other people, too numerous to mention, who are prevented from reaping the true value of their labor by unjust systems and cruel practices.
We mourn their loss of life, liberty, and opportunity.
We acknowledge that the theft of labor is the theft of generational progress. Nearly all people of color have been robbed of the opportunity and wealth that their ancestors might otherwise have passed on to them.

item.title: The Four I's of Oppression
item.description:
Any oppressive system has at its core the idea that one group is somehow better than another, and in some measure has the right to control the other group. This idea gets elaborated in many ways - more intelligent, harder working, stronger, more capable, more noble, more deserving, more advanced, chosen, normal, superior, and so on. The dominant group holds this idea about itself. And, of course, the opposite qualities are attributed to the other group - stupid, lazy, weak, incompetent, worthless, less deserving, backward, abnormal, inferior, and so on.


The idea that one group is better than another group and has the right to control the other gets embedded in the institutions of the society - the laws, the legal system and police practice, the education system and schools, hiring policies, public policies, housing development, media images, political power, etc.
When a woman makes two thirds of what a man makes in the same job, it is institutionalized sexism. When one out of every four African-American young men is currently in jail, on parole, or on probation, it is institutionalized racism.
When psychiatric institutions and associations 'diagnose' transgender people as having a mental disorder, it is institutionalized gender oppression and transphobia.
Institutional oppression does not have to be intentional.
For example, if a policy unintentionally reinforces and creates new inequalities between privileged and non-privileged groups.


The idea that one group is better than another and has the right to control the other, which gets structured into institutions, gives permission and reinforcement for individual members of the dominant group to personally disrespect or mistreat individuals in the oppressed group.
Interpersonal racism is what white people do to people of color up close--the racist jokes, the stereotypes, the beatings and harassment, the threats, etc. Similarly, interpersonal sexism is what men do to women - the sexual abuse and harassment, the violence directed at women, the belittling or ignoring of women's thinking, the sexist jokes, etc.
Most people in the dominant group are not consciously oppressive. They have internalized the negative messages about other groups, and consider their attitudes towards the other group quite normal.


These kinds of oppressive attitudes and behaviors are backed up by the institutional arrangements. This helps to clarify the confusion around what some claim to be "reverse racism." People of color can have prejudices against and anger towards white people, or individual white people. They can act out those feelings in destructive and hurtful ways towards whites. But in almost every case, this acting out will be severely punished. The force of the police and the courts, or at least a gang of whites getting even, will come crashing down on those people of color. The individual prejudice of black people, for example, is not backed up by the legal system and prevailing white institutions. The oppressed group, therefore, does not have the power to enforce its prejudices, unlike the dominant group.
For example, the racist beating of Rodney King was carried out by the institutional force of the police, and upheld by the court system. This would not have happened if King had been white and the officers black.
A simple definition of racism, as a system, is: RACISM = PREJUDICE + POWER.
Therefore, with this definition of the systemic nature of racism, people of color cannot be racist. The same formula holds true for all forms of oppression. The dominant group has its mistreatment of the target group embedded in and backed up by society's institutions and other forms of power.


The fourth way oppression works is within the groups of people who suffer the most from the mistreatment. Oppressed people internalize the ideology of inferiority, they see it reflected in the institutions, they experience disrespect interpersonally from members of the dominant group, and they eventually come to internalize the negative messages about themselves. If we have been told we are stupid, worthless, abnormal, and have been treated as if we were all our lives, then it is not surprising that we would come to believe it. This makes us feel bad.
Oppression always begins from outside the oppressed group, but by the time it gets internalized, the external oppression need hardly be felt for the damage to be done. If people from the oppressed group feel bad about themselves, and because of the nature of the system, do not have the power to direct those feelings back toward the dominant group without receiving more blows, then there are only two places to dump those feelings - on oneself and on the people in the same group. Thus, people in any target group have to struggle hard to keep from feeling heavy feelings of powerlessness or despair. They often tend to put themselves and others down, in ways that mirror the oppressive messages they have gotten all their lives. Acting out internalized oppression runs the gamut from passive powerlessness to violent aggression. It is important to understand that some of the internalized patterns of behavior originally developed to keep people alive - they had real survival value.
On the way to eliminating institutional oppression, each oppressed group has to undo the internalized beliefs, attitudes, and behaviors that stem from the oppression so that it can build unity among people in its group, support its leaders, feel proud of its history, contributions, and potential, develop the strength to challenge patterns that hold the group back, and organize itself into an effective force for social change.


Likewise, people who benefit the most from these systems internalize privilege. Privileged people involuntarily accept stereotypes and false assumptions about oppressed groups made by dominant culture. Internalized privilege includes acceptance of a belief in the inherent inferiority of the oppressed group as well as the inherent superiority or normalcy of one’s own privileged group. Internalized privilege creates an unearned sense of entitlement in members of the privileged group, and can be expressed as a denial of the existence of oppression and as paternalism.


It should be clear that none of these four aspects of oppression can exist separately. As the diagram below suggests, each is completely mixed up with the others. It is crucial at see any oppression as a system. It should also be clear that trying to challenge oppression in any of the four aspects will affect the other three.

item.title: Ethics and Cultural Awareness
item.description:
At minimum, therapists need to be culturally attuned in order to work ethically with clients.


@falicovTrainingThinkCulturally1995:
Cultural Framework:
Necessary posture or framework that develops through awareness of the role that values play for families, for therapists, and for their encounter with each other.
Culture:
Sets of shared world views and adaptive behaviors derived from simultaneous membership in a variety of contexts (geography, religion, nationality, ethnicity, race, class, gender, minority status, sexual orientation, occupation, political leanings, migratory patterns, stage of acculturation, values derived from belonging to the same generation, partaking of a single historical moment or particular ideologies)
@murphyEthicsProfessionalIssues2017:
Intersectionality:
An examination of structural, and individual process of power, privilege, and oppression. Privileged and oppressed social identities that interact simultaneously within each individual.
Social justice perspective that emphasizes social position using multiple identities and statuses.
Cultural Competence:
Broadly understood as the ability to work skillfully across cultures, engaging the perspectives and identities of both clinician and patient. Assumed to be about building knowledge of multicultural content areas.
Three main components:
Attitudes and Beliefs:
Knowledge
Skills
Develop an understanding of your own cultural background and how that influences personal attitudes, values, and beliefs.
Develop understanding and knowledge of worldviews of individuals from diverse cultural backgrounds.
Use culturally appropriate interventions.
Cultural Humility:
the ability to maintain an interpersonal stance that is other-oriented (or open to other) in relation to aspects of cultural identity that are most important for the client. Culturally humble therapists rarely assume competence. Requires the therapist to engage in self-reflection and self-critique.
Ability to express respect and lack of superiority even when cultural differences threatened to weaken alliance.
Approach clients with respectful openness, and work collaboratively with clients to understand the unique intersection of clients' various aspects of identities.
It is a disposition rather than a competency per se.
"Culturally humble therapists not only strive to be effective but also cultivate a growing awareness that they are inevitably limited in their knowledge and understanding of a client's cultural background, which motivates them to interpersonally attune themselves to the client in a quest to understand the individual client's cultural background and experience."
Developed a measure of cultural humility from client's perspective, found that it was associated with alliance, and progress, added explained variance to alliance above and beyond cultural competence measure.
Relational Ethics Perspective:
Take responsibility for the way our communication shape others' understandings.
Build relationships based on curiosity, openness, respect, and understanding of the mean making process.
Participate in meaning making in ways that allow for creating inclusive positions.
Understand how our positioning contributes to the creation of social reality.
Transparently share our positions of power and their impact on moral decisions that are made, ideally collaboratively.

item.title: Implicit Bias Training
item.description:
Implicit Bias:
The attitudes or stereotypes that affect our understanding, actions, and decisions in an unconscious manner.
Biases can be neutral, positive, or negative.
Operating outside our conscious awareness.
Based on inaccurate information or stereotypes.
Implicit biases can impact our decisions, perceptions, and behaviors.
Actions and decisions resulting from our biases create real world barriers to equity and opportunity.
It is so important to learn about implicit bias, particularly those biases that don't align with your intentions or explicit beliefs.
Implicit bias does NOT refer to those beliefs we conceal or suppress in an effort to appear non-biased.
Implicit bias is a took we possess for understanding.
Stereotype:
Beliefs that are mentally associated with a given category.



Teachers with strong, implicit pro-White biases were more likely to take a 'teach-to-the-test' approach.


Discipline decisions are challenging and stressful for everyone involved.
Differences in discipline show up strongly with regards to race and gender.
Subjective or ambiguous situations can activate implicit associations.
Students of color are more likely to receive disciplinary measures for 'disruptive behavior', 'disrespect', and 'excessive noise.'
Culturally-influenced perceptions of student behavior.
Implicit bias can turn even our best intentions into unwanted outcomes.


Research is growing around the role of implicit bias in limiting opportunities.
The race, gender, and program affiliation of the professor did not have an overall impact on the response. They responded better to White men.



It is extremely difficult - if not impossible - to uncover our implicit biases through introspection.
There are two ways to measure implicit biases:
Examining our behavior
Neurological measurement
Medical brain scanning technology
Tools like fMRIs and the IAT are often utilized together.
These associations can spill over into concepts unrelated to the 'prime'

item.title: Correlation
item.description:
The statistical association between two variables measured at ordinal, interval or ratio level. Many different 'correlation co-efficients' are used as measures of association.


We already know many ways to represent the association between two variables, both measured on at least an interval scale.
Scatterplot
Covariance sxy = (∑i = 1n (x1 - x-bar)(yi - y-bar)) ÷ n - 1 (𝜎xy for population)
Pearson correlation coefficient rxy = (sxy) ÷ (sxsy) (𝜌xy for population)
The correlation reflects the noisiness and direction of a linear relationship, but not the slope of that relationship, nor many aspects of non-linear relationships.




To test whether the sample correlation between x and y is significantly different from zero (non-directional):
H0: 𝜌 = 0 vs. H1: 𝜌 ≠ 0
Directional alternatives are also possible.
Assumptions:
Linearity:
The Pearson correlation assumes that the relationship among x and y is a linear relationship.
Independence:
Units or cases are randomly sampled from the population.


tobs = r√(n - 2) ÷ (1 - r2)
tcrit: Given the 𝛼 level, t distribution with degrees of freedom (df = n - 2)
Reject H0 if tobs > tcrit (or for negative values: tobs < tcrit)
Alternatively, reject H0 if p < 𝛼
APA Style Writing Template:
A Pearson correlation coefficient was computed to assess the linear relationship between x and y. There was a (weak / moderate / strong negative / positive) correlation between x and y, r (df) = (p-value).
Notice:
No need to report t.


Restricting the range of scores on one or both variables will reduce the strength of a correlation.
If the size of the standard deviation for one variable is reduced, everything else being equal, then the size of correlations with other variables will also be reduced. In other words, we need sufficient variation for a relationship to be evidenced through the correlation coefficient value.
HS GPA and ACT example:
The strength of correlation between GPA and ACT will be lessened if we only focus on the graduates with summa cum laude (weighted GPA 4.2 or above).


Correlation means the variables are related in some way, but correlations alone should not be used to infer cause. A high correlation between x and y might be a result of:
x causes y
y causes x
A third variable z is causing both x and y (or even more variables are involved).
Causality is not easy to prove. Application of complex statistical methods is not evidence for causality!
Causation (x -> y) can only be inferred (formalized by the 19 th-century philosopher John Stuart Mill) if:
x proceeded y
x was related to y
We can find no other plausible alternative explanation for the effect on y other than x.


'Ballpark' estimates for Pearson correlation coefficient r:
r = ± .2 (weak)
r = ± .4 (moderate)
r = ± .8 (strong)
It also depends on the nature of variables, studies, and fields (literature review).
Cohen's (1988) standards for Pearson correlation coefficient r:
r = ± .1 (weak)
r = ± .3 (moderate)
r = ± .5 (strong)




Correlation does not imply causation. With proper literature review and research design, however we can investigate how one variable (x or IV) explains the variability (variance) in the other variable (y or DV). If x is indeed a significant predictor of y, we can use x to predict y.
Still a bivariate analysis, but with a different goal in mind. For example, the school district might want to use GPA to explain the variable in ACT scores and use GPA to predict ACT.
Here we have only one predictor (IV) in the model: Simple Linear Regression (SLR).
You will learn regression models with multiple predictors, multiple linear regression (MLR), in more advanced stats classes.
Regression means you are trying to find a pattern between x and y. You are using x to predict y. We are only using one.




If we square the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) between x and y, r2 indicates the proportion of the Variance in y that can be explained by x.
HS GPA and ACT example: r = .698
Square it:
r2 = (. 698)2 ≈ .487
This indicates 48.7% of the variance in ACT scores can be explained (or accounted for) by GPA.
Recall r ranges from -1 to 1. What does it mean for the range of r2?
Recall 'ballpark' effect size:
Weak (|r| ≥ .2)
Weak (r2 ≥ .04 or 4%)
Moderate (|r| ≥ .4)
Moderate (r2 ≥ .16 or 16%)
Strong (|r| ≥ .8)
Strong (r2 ≥ .64 or 64%)


xi: IV data point for subject i
yi: DV data point for subject i
yi: Expected/predicted value for subject i (i.e., the regression line)

𝛽0: Intercept (Constant)
𝛽1: Slope (How much DV increases as IV increases by 1 unit)


Finding b0 and b1 (regression coefficients) for the regression line:

Best estimates for b's are the ones that provide minimal error over any other collection of b's. Working with the squared values, our goal is to find estimate b0 and b1 to minimize the error sum of squares:
SSE =
The optimal solution:
b0 = y-hat - b1x-bar
Regression line goes through both means of x and y!
The slope is determined by the correlation between x and y with a scale of y per change in x.


Analyze -> Regression -> Linear
Define DV and IV (one IV for SLR)
Usually you'd already review descriptive statistics and correlations before running a regression, but you can also ask SPSS to report Descriptive in the Statistics option.
Many other options are for MLR only.
The default SPSS output has 3 sections:
Model Summary (How much variance in DV is explained by the model)
ANOVA Table (Model significance)
Regression Coefficients (Equation for the regression line)


Total variability (variance) in DV is partitioned into two parts:
What we can explain by the model (regression)
What we still cannot explain (error)
Regression sum of squares (SSR)
Error Sum of Squares (SSE)
Total Sum of Squares (SSTO)
SSTO = SSR + SSE
SSR, SSE, and SSTO are available in the ANOVA table


R2 indicates the proportion of variance in DV explained (accounted for) by the model, which can be considered the overall model fit.
R2 = (SSR) ÷ (SSTO) = 1 - (SSE ÷ SSTO) = (Multiple R)2
In SLR, R2 equals the square of the Pearson correlation between x and y
Multiple R is the correlation between yi and y-hati (always positive)
In SLR, Multiple R = | rxy |


Omnibus:
Comprising several items
"Congress passed an omnibus anticrime package."
The omnibus test is used to evaluate the significance of overall regression model. Statistics used to conduct the omnibus test are available in the ANOVA table.
Many different (equivalent) ways to represent the omnibus test, but they are asking the same question:
Is the regression model good enough to be used to explain/predict DV?
Since we are comparing variances (SSR and SSE), the sample statistics is compared to a critical F statistics, given the significance level (usually α=. 05). General idea:
Large observed F means much variance in DV can be explained by the model (desired)!


H0: β1 = 0
H1: β1 ≠ 0
H0: y-hat = y-bar
H1: y-hat = b0 +b1x (DV cannot be predicted by model)
H0: ρ = 0 (ρ is the population correlation between model and data, estimated by Multiple R)
H1: ρ > 0
H0: ρ2 = 0
H1: ρ2 > 0




Compare Fobs to the critical F(1, n -2)
Reject H0 if Fobs > F(1, n -2)
Alternatively, reject H0 if p < α
For APA style writing, make sure you report the F statistic along with both degrees of freedom and the p-value.

MLR is used when you want to understand the relationship between one Dependent Variable and two or more Independent Variable. It is commonly applied in scenarios such as:

Controlling for Confounding Variables

In Multiple Linear Regression (MLR) multicollinearity is said to exist when two or more of the independent variables are themselves highly correlated, a situation that makes it difficult to establish the effect each has on the dependent variable.

An assessment of the normality of data is a prerequisite for many statistical tests because normal data is an underlying assumption in parametric testing.


SPSS allows you to test all of these procedures within Explore command. The Explore command can be used in isolation if you are testing normality in one group or splitting your dataset into one or more groups. If you have 2 or more categorical, independent variables, the Explore command on its own is not enough and you will have to use the Split File command also.


Click Analyze -> Descriptives -> Explore

Transfer the variable that needs to be tested for normality into the Dependent List box.
Click on Statistics. Leave Descriptives selected.
Click the Plots. Select Factor Levels Together under Boxplots. Select Stem-and-Leaf under Descriptive. Select Normality Plots with Tests.


When testing for normality, we are mainly interested in the Tests of Normality table and the Normal Q-Q Plots, our numerical and graphical methods to test for the normality of data, respectively.



The above table presents the results from two well-known tests of normality, namely the Kolmogorov-Smirnov Test and the Shapiro-Wilk. The Shapiro-Wilk Test is more appropriate for small sample sizes (<50 samples), but can also handle sample sizes as large as 2000.
If the Sig. value of the Shapiro-Wilk Test is greater than p = .05, the data is normal. If it is below 0.05, the data significantly deviate from a normal distribution.



In order to determine normality graphically, we can use the output of a normal P-P plot. If the data are normally distributed, the data points will be close to the diagonal line. If the data points stray from the line in an obvious non-linear fashion, the data are not normally distributed.
If the points are generally along the diagonal, the assumption is met.
If you are at all unsure of being able to correctly interpret the graph, rely on the numeric methods instead because it can take a fair bit of experience to correctly judge the normality of data based on plots.



If the histogram is approximately normal, the assumption is met.
The distribution curve is normal/bell shaped.


The assumption is met if the skewness and kurtosis is between +2 and -2.

item.title: T-Test
item.description:
A statistical procedure designed to assess whether differences in the means of two groups reflect differences in their respective populations or are simply due to chance.



Non-directional (two-tailed):
To test if mean where sample came from (µ) is significantly different from hypothesized mean (µ0).
H0: µ = µ0 vs. H1: µ ≠ µ0
Alternatively in terms of mean difference:
H0: µ - µ0 = 0 vs. H1: µ - µ0 ≠ 0
Directional (One-Tailed):
H0: µ ≤ µ0 vs. H1: µ > µ0
H0: µ ≥ µ0 vs. H1: µ < µ0
Reject H0 if tobs = (x bar - µ0) ÷ (s ÷ √n) falls into the critical region (determined by tcrit given the df)


Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-sample t-test
Pick variable and enter the Test Value (µ0)
SPSS reports p-values for both one-sided (directional) and two-sided (non-directional) tests. However, confidence interval (CI) of mean difference is only constructed for two-sided.

Set up hypotheses based on the research question.
Where does the sample/observed mean lie on the sampling distribution?
Given the confidence level 100 (1 - 𝜎)%, what is considered extreme evidence?
Compared to the critical value, is the sample mean extreme enough to be considered different from µ0?


For one-sample t-test (population σ unknown), we use Cohen’s d to report effect size.
Cohen’s d = (x bar - μ0) ÷ s
Recall Cohen’s d for one-sample z-test:
d = (x bar - μ0) ÷ 𝜎
So, here sample SD (𝜎) is used to estimate 𝜎.
Notice, unlike z or t scores, effect sizes are not affected by sample size
Size of Cohen's d (by convention):
Small effect:
d = ± 0.2
Medium effect:
d = ± 0.5
Large effect:
d = ± 0.8


SPSS reports both one-sided and two-sided p-values, but only two-sided CI is reported.
To obtain one-sided upper or lower confidence limits, run a test doubling the 𝛼 (alpha) level
This doe snot affect the p-values reported in the output.
Say if you are conducting a directional test a 95% confidence level and want to see LCL or UCL, you can change the confidence interval percentage from 95% to 90% in Options.
The lower end of reported 90% CI would be 95% LCL (Lower Control Limit), and the upper end of reported 90% CI would be 95% (Upper Control Limit).
Any variation detected inside the control limits probably occurred by chance. On the other hand, variation outside of the control limits likely occurred due to special causes. The upper control limit (UCL) and the lower control limit (LCL) serve as boundaries for expected deviation in data.

Control Charts


A one-sample t-test was conducted at an alpha level of .05 to answer the research question: Is OSU students’ willingness to pay (WTP) for Gardyn significantly different from the retail price $899? The null hypothesis stated that WTP would not differ from the retail price. The alternative hypothesis stated that WTP would differ from the retail price.
Based on a random sample of 20 OSU students, there was a mean WTP of $181.9 and a standard deviation of $231.215. Then compared against the hypothesized mean of $899, the one-sample t-test was statistically significant, t(19) = -13.87, p < .001, indicating WTP is significantly different from $899.
In addition, the effect size Cohen’s d was -3.101, generally interpreted as a large effect (Cohen, 1988), indicating that there is about 3 standard deviations difference between WTP and retail price, with the WTP lower than the retail price.


7. Paired-Sample T-Test


Nondirectional:
Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly different from pre-score (µ1)
H0: µ2 = µ1 vs. H1: µ2 ≠ µ1
Alternatively, in terms of mean difference:
H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0
The mean difference is the difference in pre- and post-scores, so a paired-sample t-test is identical to a one-sample t-test, testing the difference in scores against the hypothesized (test) value!
Directional:
Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly greater from pre-score (µ1).
H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0
Directional:
Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly smaller than pre-scores (µ1):
H0: µ2 - µ1 ≥ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 < 0


tobs = d ÷ sd-bar or d ÷ (sd ÷ √n)
d is the mean difference and sd-bar is the standard error of the mean difference:
sd-bar = sd ÷ √n
sd is the standard deviation of the difference scores (i.e., like any other standard deviation only this one is computed from the difference scores rather than raw scores).
n is the total number of pairs.
Recall in one-sample t-test:
tobs = ( - µ0) (s ÷ √n)
Where is µ0?


Given 𝛼 level, nondirectional or directional, and degree of freedom (df = n - 1), critical t can be found on the t-table (if df is available).
Recall rejection region is outside of critical t('s) toward the tail (s).
Reject H0 if a positive tobs > tcrit (for negative values: tobs < tcrit) or p < 𝛼 (SPSS)
𝛼 level is usually .05 (95% confidence level)


Nondirectional:
100 (1 - 𝛼)% CI:
± tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar
± tdf, 𝛼/2 x (sd-bar ÷ √n)
To test greater (significant increase in post-scores):
100 (1 - 𝛼)% LCL: - tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar
To test smaller (significant decrease in post-scores):
100 (1 - 𝛼)% UCL: + tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar


DV data recorded as 2 variables (e.g., pre-score and post-score) in SPSS
IV (treatment, intervention) is usually not recorded as a variable in SPSS
Analyze -> Compare Means -> Paired-Samples t-test
Move the two variables of interest (e.g., pre-score and post-score) to the paired variable 1 and variable 2.
Notice the mean difference SPSS computes is variable 1 minus variable 2, so sometimes the sign of observed t can be confusing. However, you can easily figure out if the effect is positive or negative based on the descriptive statistics. I like to enter post-score as variable 1 and pre-score as variable 2 so I can see the change (positive or negative) from pre-score to post-score.


Cohen's d = d-bar ÷ sd-bar
Recall Cohen's d for one-sample t-test:
d = ( - µ0) ÷ s
Size of Cohen's d (by convention):
d = ±0.2: Small effect
d = ±0.5: Medium effect
d = ±0.8: Large effect


The pre-video and post-video negative emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 4.80 (SD = 0.926) and a post-score mean of 4.60 (SD = 1.028). Thus, negative emotion changed by -0.20 (decrease) after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly smaller than zero (significant decrease after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly lower than the pre-score, t(33) = -2.393, p = 0.011. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance.
The effect size Cohen's d was -0.410. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a small to medium effect.
The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the negative emotion significantly decreased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests about 0.4 standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score.


The pre-video and post-video positive emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 3.76 (SD = 0.998) and a post-score mean of 4.82 (SD = 1.014). Thus, positive emotion increased by 1.06 after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly greater than zero (significant increase after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly higher than the pre-score, t(33) = 6.448, p < .001. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance.
The effect size Cohen's d was 1.106. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a large effect.
The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the positive emotion significantly increased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests more than one standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score.

Observations come from a random sample, and subjects are independent of each other.
Variable is measured on at least an interval level scale.
Sampling distribution of the mean is normal, and CLT assures that for big samples (say 30).

item.title: Variance Inflation Factor (VIF)
item.description:
The Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) is a measure of multicollinearity in regression analysis. It quantifies how much the variance of a regression coefficient is inflated due to collinearity among predictor variables.
VIF = 1 → No collinearity.
VIF between 1 and 5 → Moderate collinearity (acceptable).
VIF > 10 → High collinearity (problematic, requires corrective action).
A high VIF suggests that one independent variable is highly correlated with others, making it difficult to determine the individual effect of each predictor.

You can calculate VIF in SPSS using Multiple Linear Regression:


Click Analyze → Regression → Linear.
Specify Variables:
Move the dependent variable to the Dependent box.
Move the independent variables to the Independent(s) box.
Enable Collinearity Diagnostics:
Click Statistics.
Check Collinearity diagnostics and Tolerance/VIF.
Click Continue.
Run the Analysis: Click OK.


The Coefficients Table in SPSS will include two relevant columns:
Tolerance: The proportion of variance in a predictor not explained by the other predictors (Tolerance = 1/VIF).
VIF (Variance Inflation Factor): The degree to which variance is inflated due to multicollinearity.



If VIF < 5, multicollinearity is not a major concern.
If VIF > 5, review the correlation between predictors.
If VIF > 10, severe multicollinearity exists, and corrective action (e.g., removing variables, combining correlated variables, or using Principal Component Analysis) may be needed.


"A multiple regression was conducted to predict Y based on X1, X2, and X3. The VIF values were examined for multicollinearity, with all values below 5, indicating no severe multicollinearity concerns (X1 VIF = 1.18, X2 VIF = 3.12, X3 VIF = 11.11). However, X3 showed high collinearity (VIF > 10), suggesting a need for further analysis or model revision."

The simple model (i.e., mean-only model) is not very informative and has a lot of error.

Our model-building goal is to improve prediction and thereby reduce the error.
To improve prediction and reduce error, we add a predictor variable (X) to the model.
This enhanced model is the beginning of a 'predictive formula' that predicts individual outcome variable scores (Y) better than just predicting the mean.


To use a bivariate regression model, identify two types of variables:
Predictor, or known variable (x)
Outcome, or to-be-predicted variable (y)
Regression analysis provides an equation that corresponds to a line that best predicts y scores from x scores.
The model Population Parameter will be designated with a Greek letter (β).

We can predict a person's score on an outcome (dependent) variable (Y-Hat) based on what we know about that person's score on a predictor (independent) variable (x).
If variables x and y are related to each other, then adding x to our model improves prediction and produces less error (SSE) than the simple model generated.

item.title: One-Way Independent ANOVA
item.description:
Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)
Dependent Variable (Y; continuous)
Independent Variable (X; categorical, grouping variable)
It is equivalent to a t-test but can have more levels (groups tested at once).


Used to compare means of two or more independent groups to determine if there is a statistically significant difference between them.


Testing whether different teaching methods (Group A, B, C) produce different average exam scores.





State the null and alternative hypotheses:
H0: µ1 = µ2 ... (µ represents the population mean for each group)
H1: µ1 ≠ µ2 ... (at least one mean is different)




Click Analyze > Descriptive Statistics > Explore > Tests for Normality (Shapiro-Wilk Test, Q-Q Plot, Histogram)


Go to Analyze > General Linear Model > Univariate
Move your Dependent Variable (e.g., exam scores) to the Dependent Variable box.
Move your Independent Variable (grouping variable) (e.g., teaching method) to the Fixed Factor(s) box.
Click Options, check Descriptive Statistics and Homogeneity Tests. Click Continue.
Click OK for output and Paste for syntax editor.




Interpretation: Since p = 0.12 (p > 0.05), the assumption of equal variances is met.



Interpretation: The significant F (F (2, 57) = 5.43, p = 0.008) indicates that at least one group mean is significantly different.


"A one-way ANOVA was conducted to examine the effect of teaching method on exam scores. Results indicated a statistically significant difference among the groups, F (2, 57) = 5.43, p = 0.008. Levene's test confirmed the assumption of homogeneity of variances, p = 0.12. Post hoc comparisons using Tukey's HSD indicated that Group A scored significantly higher than Group C (p < 0.05)."



Compute SST
SSE = ∑ (Yi - Y-hati)2
Compute the Degrees of Freedom
Degrees of Freedom Between Groups
dfBG = k - 1 (k is the number of levels / groups / conditions) (between groups)
Degrees of Freedom Within Groups (Error)
dfE = N - k (N is the total number of participants in a study) (within group / error)
Sums of Degrees of Freedom
dfTot = N - 1
Compute F Ratio

Variance between groups (proportion of variability in Y explained by X)
Variance within groups (proportion of variability in Y unexplained by X)
MSBG (Mean square, instead of getting the sum of squares of error, we will be getting the mean square; BG: between group; E: error or within group)

Values for the F statistic should all be positive. F = 1 means no mean difference because the between and within group variabilities would be the same. The higher your F, the greater change of it being significant (would mean there is a much higher variability between groups than you see within groups)
Complete F Table


Compare the calculated F-value against the F-crit value
If F-value is greater than F-crit then you can say there is a statistically significant difference between the means of the groups.
When looking at the F-crit table, the df between is horizontal and df within is vertical.
Make a Decision
Write up the F-values (i.e., F (1,10) = 41.227, p < .001).
A bar graph can be used to visually depict the differences as well.
Example Language:
"We conducted a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) to examine whether there was a mean difference of depression scores between subjects who were diagnosed with depression and who were not. The ANOVA results showed that there was a statistically significant mean difference between the two groups (F (1,22) = 117.42, p < .001)."


The one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) is used to determine whether there are any statistically significant differences between the means of three or more independent (unrelated) groups.


The one-way ANOVA compares the means between the groups you are interested in and determines whether any of those means are statistically significantly different from each other. Specifically, it tests the null hypothesis:

Where µ = group mean and k = number of groups. If, however, the one-way ANOVA returns a statistically significant result, we accept the alternative hypothesis, which is that there are at least two group means that are statistically significantly different from each other.
The one-way ANOVA is an Omnibus test statistic, and cannot tell you which specific groups were statistically significantly different from each other, only that at least two groups were. To determine which specific groups differed from each other, you need to use a post hoc test.


It is used to test research questions and hypotheses where you want to compare the means of three or more groups on a single dependent variable. You are asking if there is a significant difference between the groups based on a single categorical independent variable with multiple levels.
If you are dealing with individuals, you are likely to encounter this situation using two different types of study design:
One study design is to recruit a group of individuals and then randomly split this group into three or more smaller groups (i.e., each participant is allocated to one, and only one, group). You then get each group to undertake different tests (or put them under different conditions) and measure the outcome/response on the same dependent variable.
For example, a researcher wishes to know whether different pacing strategies affect the time to complete a marathon. The researcher randomly assigns a group of volunteers to either a group that (a) starts slow and then increases their speed, (b) starts fast and slows down or (c) runs at a steady pace throughout. The time to complete the marathon is the outcome (dependent) variable.

A second study design is to recruit a group of individuals and then split them into groups based on some independent variable. Again, each individual will be assigned to one group only. This independent variable is sometimes called an attribute independent variable because you are splitting the group based on some attribute that they possess (e.g., their level of education; every individual has a level of education, even if it is 'none'). Each group is then measured on the same dependent variable having undergone the same task or condition (or none at all).
For example, a researcher is interested in determining whether there are differences in leg strength between amateur, semi-professional and provessional rugby players. The force/strength measured on an isokinetic machine is the dependent variable.



Every time you conduct a t-test there is a chance that you will make a Type I Errors. This error is usually 5%. By running two t-tests on the same data you will have increased your chance of "making a mistake" to 10%. The formula for determining the new error rate for multiple t-tests is not as simple as multiplying 5% by the number of tests. However, if you are only making a few multiple comparisons, the results are very similar if you do. As such, three t-tests would be 15% (actually, 14.3%) and so on. These are unacceptable errors. An ANOVA controls for these errors so that the Type I Errors remains at 5% and you can be more confident that any statistically significant result you find is not just running lots of tests.


When you choose to analyze your data using a one-way ANOVA, part of the process involves checking to make sure that the data you want to analyze can actually be analyzed using a one-way ANOVA. You need to do this because it is only appropriate to use a one-way ANOVA if your data "passes" six assumptions that are required for a one-way ANOVA to give you a valid result.


Your dependent variable should be measured at the interval or ratio level (Interval Variable and Ratio Variable) (i.e., they are Continuous Variable; IQ score, exam scores, weight, etc).
The dependent variable is normally distributed in each group that is being compared in the one-way ANOVA (technically, it is the residuals that need to be normally distributed, but the results will be the same).
For example, if we were comparing three groups (e.g., amateur, semi-professional, and professional rugby players) on their leg strength, their leg strength values (Dependent Variable) would have to be normally distributed for the amateur group of players, normally distributed for the semi-professionals and normally distributed for the professional player. You can test for normality in SPSS.
Testing for Normality
There is homogeneity of variances. This means that the population variances in each group are equal. If you use SPSS Statistics, Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variances is included in the output when you run a one-way ANOVA in SPSS Statistics.
Independence of Observations. This is mostly a study design issue and, as such, you will need to determine whether you believe it is possible that your observations are not independent based on your study design.


Your Independent Variable should consist of two or more categorical, independent groups. Typically, a one-way ANOVA is used when you have three or more categorical, independent groups, but it can be used for just two groups (but an Independent Samples T-Test Independent Samples T-Test is more commonly used for two groups)
Example independent variables that meet this criterion include ethnicity (e.g., 3 groups: Caucasian, African American, and Hispanic), physical activity level (e.g., 4 groups: sedentary, low, moderate, and high), profession (e.g., 5 groups: surgeon, doctor, nurse, dentist, therapist) and so forth.


You should have Independence of Observations, which means that there is no relationship between the observations in each group or between the groups themselves.
For example, there must be different participants in each group with no participant being in more than one group. This is more of a study design issue than something you can test for.
If your study fails this assumption, you will need to use another statistical test instead of the one-way ANOVA (e.g., a repeated measures design).


There should be no significant outliers. Outliers are simply data points within your data that do not follow the usual pattern (e.g., in a study of 100 students' IQ scores, where the mean score was 108 with only a small variation between students, one student had a score of 156, which is very unusual, and may even put her in the top 1% of IQ scores globally).
The problem with outliers is that they can have a negative effect on the one-way ANOVA, reducing the validity of your results.


Your Dependent Variable should be approximately normally distributed for each category of the Independent Variable. We talk about the one-way ANOVA only requiring approximately normal data because it is quite 'robust' to violations of normality, meaning that assumption can be a little violated and still provide valid results. You can test for normality using the Shapiro-Wilk test of normality, which is easily tested for using SPSS Statistics.


There needs to be Homogeneity of Variances. You can test this assumption in SPSS Statistics using Levene's test for homogeneity of variances. If your data fails this assumption, you will need to not only carry out a Welch ANOVA instead of a one-way ANOVA, which you can do using SPSS Statistics, but also use a different post hoc test.


The one-way ANOVA is considered a robust test against the normality assumption. This means that it tolerates violations to its normality assumption rather well. As regards the normality of group data, the one-way ANOVA can tolerate data that is non-normal (skewed or kurtotic distributions) with only a small effect on the Type I Errors rate. However, platykurtosis can have a profound effect when your group sizes are small. This leaves you with two options:
Transform your data using various algorithms so that the shape of your distributions become normally distributed
Choose the nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis H Test which does not require the assumption of normality.
There are two tests that you can run that are applicable when the assumption of homogeneity of variances has been violated.
Welch
Brown and Forsythe test.
Alternatively, you can run a Kruskal-Wallis H Test. For most situations, it has been shown that the Welch test is the best. Both the Welch and Brown and Forsythe tests are available in SPSS.
A lack of independence of cases has been stated as the most serious assumptions to fail. Often, there is little you can do that offers a good solution to this problem.





Analyze -> Compare Means -> One-Way ANOVA

Add Dependent Variable to the Dependent List box, and add the Independent Variable to the Factor box.
Click Options. Check the box for Means Plot, then click Continue.
Click OK when finished.

ONEWAY Sprint BY Smoking /PLOT MEANS /MISSING ANALYSIS.


The Dependent Variable. This is the variable whose means will be compared between the samples (groups). You may run multiple means comparisons simultaneously by selecting more than one dependent variable.


The Independent Variable. The categories (or groups) of the independent variable will define which samples will be compared. The independent variable must have at least two categories (groups), but usually has three or more groups when used in a One-Way ANOVA.


Specify contrasts, or planned comparisons, to be conducted after the overall ANOVA test.
When the initial F-test indicates that significant differences exist between group means, contrasts are useful for determining which specific means are significantly different when you have specific hypotheses that you wish to test. Contrasts are decided before analyzing the data (i.e., priori). Contrasts break down the variance into component parts. They may involve using weights, non-orthogonal comparisons, standard contrasts, and polynomial contrasts (trend analysis).



Request post hoc (also known as multiple comparisons) tests. Specific post hoc tests can be selected by checking the associated boxes.
When the initial F test indicates that significant differences exist between group means, post hoc tests are useful for determining which specific means are significantly different when you do not have specific hypotheses you wish to test. Post hoc tests compare each pair of means (like T-Test s), but unlike T-Test s, they correct the significance estimate to account for the multiple comparisons.



Multiple comparisons options that assume homogeneity of variance (each group has equal variance).


By default, a 2-sided hypothesis test is selected. Alternatively, a directional, one-sided hypothesis can be specified if you choose to use a Dunnett post hoc test. Click the box next to Dunnett and then specify whether the Control Category is the Last or First group, numerically, of your grouping variable. In the Test area, click either < Control or > Control. The one-tailed options require that you specify whether you predict that the mean for the specified control group will be less than (> Control) or greater than (< Control) another group.


Multiple comparisons options that do not assume equal variances.


The desired cutoff for statistical significance. By default, significance is set to 0.05.


Clicking Options will produce a window where you can specify which Statistics to include in the output (Descriptive, Fixed and Random Effects, Homogeneity of Variance Test, Brown-Forsythe, Welch), whether to include a Means Plot, and how the analysis will address Missing Values (i.e., Exclude cases analysis by analysis or Exclude cases listwise). Click Continue when you are finished making specifications.






You will have calculated the following results or obtained them from SPSS.


"There was a statistically significant difference between groups as determined by one-way ANOVA (F (2, 27) = 4.467, p = .021)." this is all you will need to write for the one-way ANOVA per se. However, you will probably also want to report means ± Standard Deviation (SD) s for your groups, as well as follow up a statistically significant result with a post hoc test.
The general form of writing the result of a one-way ANOVA is as follow:

You should not report the result as 'Significant difference,' but instead report it as 'statistically significant difference.' this is because your devision as to whether the result is significant or not should not be based solely on your statistical test.


Report the result of the one-way ANOVA (e.g., 'There were no statistically significant differences between group means as determined by one-way ANOVA (F (2, 27) = 1.397, p = .15)'). Running a post hoc test is usually not warranted and should not be carried out.


You need to report your results. You then need to follow-up the one-way ANOVA by running a post hoc test.


You need to perform the same procedures as above, but add into your results section that this assumption was violated and you needed to run a Welch F test.


ANOVA test tells you whether you have an overall difference between your groups, but it does not tell you which specific groups differed - post hoc tests do. Because post hoc tests are run to confirm where the differences occurred between groups, they should only be run when you have a shown an overall statistically significant difference in group means (i.e., a statistically significant one-way ANOVA result). Post hoc tests attempt to control the experiment-wise error rate (usually alpha = 0.05) in the same manner that the one-way ANOVA is used instead of multiple t-tests. Post hoc tests are termed a posteriori tests; that is, performed after the event (the event in this case being a study).


There are a great number of different post hoc tests that you can use. However, you should only run one post hoc test - do not run multiple post hoc tests. For a one-way ANOVA, you will probably find that just two tests need to be considered. If your data met the assumption of homogeneity of variances, use Tukey's honestly significant difference (HSD) post hoc test.
Note that if you use SPSS Statistics, Tukey's HSD test is simply referred to as 'Tukey' in the post post hoc multiple comparisons dialogue box. If your data did not meet the homogeneity fo variances assumption, you should consider running the Games Howell post hoc test.

item.title: Paired T-Test
item.description:
AKA dependent t-test:
Dependent variable (DV):
Scores being compared
Measured on at least an interval level scale
Often used to compare post-score to pre-score
Independent variable (IV):
The treatment or intervention
Typical research question:
Is there a mean difference between the post-score and pre-score?
Also used to compare twins, couples, eyeballs, etc.


20 weeks of cognitive behavioral therapy -> Amount and severity of depressive symptoms
Intervention -> Students' math proficiency
Constraint induced movement therapy -> hand function


One-group pretest-posttest design:
O1 (pre) X O2 (post)
One-group pretest-posttest design using a double pretest:
O1 O2 X O3
One-group pretest-posttest design using a nonequivalent dependent variable:
(O1 A, O1 B) x (O2 B, O2 B)
The removed-treatment design:
O1 x O2 (O3) x O4
The repeated-treatment design:
O1 x O2 x O3 x O4


Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples
NR (Not Random) O1 X O2
NR (Not Random) O1 O2
Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using a double pretest
NR O1 O2 X O3
NR O1 O2 O3
Untreated control group design with dependent pretest and posttest samples using switching replications
NR O1 x O2 (O3) x O4
NR O1 O2 (O3) x O4
Untreated control group design dependent pretest and posttest samples using reversed-treatment control group
NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post)
NR O1 (pre) X O2 (post)


Nondirectional:
Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly different from pre-score (µ1)
H0: µ2 = µ1 vs. H1: µ2 ≠ µ1
Alternatively, in terms of mean difference:
H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0
The mean difference is the difference in pre- and post-scores, so a paired-sample t-test is identical to a one-sample t-test, testing the difference in scores against the hypothesized (test) value!
Directional:
Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly greater from pre-score (µ1).
H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0
Directional:
Test if post-score (µ2) is significantly smaller than pre-scores (µ1):
H0: µ2 - µ1 ≥ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 < 0

One Sample Statistics

One-Sample Test


For negative emotion change (hypothesized to decrease), the one-sample t-test is significant, t (33) = -2.393, p = .011. The mean difference is -0.20 (negative emotion decreased after watching the video). The 95% upper confidence limit -. 0585 below zero also provides evidence that the test is significant (change significantly smaller than 0).
For positive emotion change (hypothesized to increase), the one-sample t-test is significant, t (33) = 6.448, p < .001. The mean difference is 1.06 (positive emotion increased after watching the video). The 95% lower confidence limit .7809 above zero also provides evidence that the test is significant (change significantly greater than 0).


tobs = d ÷ sd-bar or d ÷ (sd ÷ √n)
d is the mean difference and sd-bar is the standard error of the mean difference:
sd-bar = sd ÷ √n
sd is the standard deviation of the difference scores (i.e., like any other standard deviation only this one is computed from the difference scores rather than raw scores).
n is the total number of pairs.
Recall in one-sample t-test:
tobs = ( - µ0) (s ÷ √n)
Where is µ0?


Given 𝛼 level, nondirectional or directional, and degree of freedom (df = n - 1), critical t can be found on the t-table (if df is available).
Recall rejection region is outside of critical t('s) toward the tail (s).
Reject H0 if a positive tobs > tcrit (for negative values: tobs < tcrit) or p < 𝛼 (SPSS)
𝛼 level is usually .05 (95% confidence level)


Nondirectional:
100 (1 - 𝛼)% CI:
± tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar
± tdf, 𝛼/2 x (sd-bar ÷ √n)
To test greater (significant increase in post-scores):
100 (1 - 𝛼)% LCL: - tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar
To test smaller (significant decrease in post-scores):
100 (1 - 𝛼)% UCL: + tdf, 𝛼/2 x sd-bar


DV data recorded as 2 variables (e.g., pre-score and post-score) in SPSS
IV (treatment, intervention) is usually not recorded as a variable in SPSS
Analyze -> Compare Means -> Paired-Samples t-test
Move the two variables of interest (e.g., pre-score and post-score) to the paired variable 1 and variable 2.
Notice the mean difference SPSS computes is variable 1 minus variable 2, so sometimes the sign of observed t can be confusing. However, you can easily figure out if the effect is positive or negative based on the descriptive statistics. I like to enter post-score as variable 1 and pre-score as variable 2 so I can see the change (positive or negative) from pre-score to post-score.

Paired Samples Statistics

Paired Samples Correlations

Paired Samples Test


For negative emotion change:
sd-bar = sd ÷ √n = .48742 ÷ √34 = .08359
tobs = d-bar ÷ sd = - .2000 ÷ .08359 = -2.393
For positive emotion change:
sd-bar = sd ÷ √n = .95754 ÷ √34 = .16422
tobs = d-bar ÷ sd = 1.05882 ÷ .16422 = 6.448


Mean difference from pre- to post-score is hypothesized to decrease (one-tailed test).
H0: µ2 - µ1 ≥ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 < 0
Mean difference d-bar = - .2000, SD sd = .48742, sd-bar = .08359
tobs = -2.393, df = 33, p = .011
Since the p-value (. 011) is smaller than the 𝛼 level (. 05), we can reject the H0 and conclude that participants' negative emotion significantly decreased after watching the cat videos.


Mean difference from pre- to post-score is hypothesized to increase (one-tailed test).
H0: µ2 - µ1 ≤ 0 vs. H1: µ2 - µ1 > 0
Mean difference d-bar = 1.05882, SD sd = .95754, sd-bar = .16422
tobs = 6.448, df = 33, p < .001
Since the p-value is very small (< .001), we can reject the H0 and conclude that participants' positive emotion significantly increased after watching the cat videos.


Cohen's d = d-bar ÷ sd-bar
Recall Cohen's d for one-sample t-test:
d = ( - µ0) ÷ s
Size of Cohen's d (by convention):
d = ±0.2: Small effect
d = ±0.5: Medium effect
d = ±0.8: Large effect

Paired Samples Effect Sizes


For negative emotion change, Cohen's d (- 0.410) suggests a small to medium effect.
For positive emotion change, the effect size (d = 1.106) is quite large.


The pre-video and post-video negative emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 4.80 (SD = 0.926) and a post-score mean of 4.60 (SD = 1.028). Thus, negative emotion changed by -0.20 (decrease) after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly smaller than zero (significant decrease after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly lower than the pre-score, t(33) = -2.393, p = 0.011. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance.
The effect size Cohen's d was -0.410. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a small to medium effect.
The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the negative emotion significantly decreased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests about 0.4 standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score.


The pre-video and post-video positive emotion scores were collected from a sample of 34 participants, with a pre-score of 3.76 (SD = 0.998) and a post-score mean of 4.82 (SD = 1.014). Thus, positive emotion increased by 1.06 after the video. The paired-sample t-test was conducted to determine if this change was significantly greater than zero (significant increase after the video), and the results indicate that the post-score was significantly higher than the pre-score, t(33) = 6.448, p < .001. The null hypothesis was rejected at the .05 level of significance.
The effect size Cohen's d was 1.106. Using Cohen's (1988) guidelines, this is interpreted as a large effect.
The results provide evidence to support the conclusion that the positive emotion significantly increased after watching cat videos. The effect size suggests more than one standard deviation unit difference between pre-score and post-score.


The results from the pre-test (M = 13.5, SD = 2.4) and post-test (M = 16.2, SD = 2.7) memory task indicate that the presence of caffeine in the bloodstream resulted in an improvement in memory recall, t(19) = 3.1, p = .006.
There was a significant increase in the volume of alcohol consumed in the week after the end of semester (M = 8.7, SD = 3.1) compared to the week before the end of semester (M = 3.2, SD = 1.5), t(52) = 4.8, p < .001
How to Report the Result of a T-Test (APA style)


If you're hypothesis testing, restate your hypothesis. If your t-test is one-tailed, you need to say so.
It's preferred to report the exact p-value unless it's smaller than .001. You need to state your alpha level (usually .05) early in the results section. If your p-value is smaller than .001, it's conventional simply to state p < .001 (NEVER report p = 0)
Remember to drop the leading 0 from the p-value.
No need to provide a formula for observed t in your paper.


Observations are from a random sample, and the scores are independent of each other.
Dependent variable of interest is measured on at least an interval scale.
Difference scores (d's) are normally distributed.
Typically considered robust to violations of non-normality, especially for big sample (n > 30)
If one of the samples is highly skewed (particularly for a one-tailed test), a lot of error will tend to be built into the difference scores. Other non-parametric analyses would be better alternatives.

item.title: Ratio Variable
item.description:
Ratio variables are interval variables, but with the added condition that 0 of the measurement indicates that there is none of that variable. (Continuous Variable are further categorized as either Interval Variable or Ratio Variable)
Example:
Temperature measured in degrees Celsius or Fahrenheit is not a ratio variable because 0 degrees Celsius does not mean there is no temperature. However, temperature measured in Kelvin is a ratio variable as 0 Kelvin (often called absolute zero) indicates that there is no temperature whatsoever. Other examples of ratio variables include height, mass, distance, etc.
The name 'ratio' reflects the fact that you can use the ratio of measurements. So, for example, a distance of ten meters is twice the distance of 5 meters.

item.title: Simple Linear Regression (SLR)
item.description:
Also known as Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
Correlation does not imply causation. With proper literature review and research design, however we can investigate how one variable (x or IV) explains the variability (variance) in the other variable (y or DV). If x is indeed a significant predictor of y, we can use x to predict y.
Still a bivariate analysis, but with a different goal in mind. For example, the school district might want to use GPA to explain the variable in ACT scores and use GPA to predict ACT.
Here we have only one predictor (IV) in the model: Simple Linear Regression (SLR).
Regression means you are trying to find a pattern between x and y. You are using x to predict y. We are only using one.




If we square the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) between x and y, r2 indicates the proportion of the Variance in y that can be explained by x.
HS GPA and ACT example: r = .698
Square it:
r2 = (. 698)2 ≈ .487
This indicates 48.7% of the variance in ACT scores can be explained (or accounted for) by GPA.
Recall r ranges from -1 to 1. What does it mean for the range of r2?
Recall 'ballpark' effect size:
Weak (|r| ≥ .2)
Weak (r2 ≥ .04 or 4%)
Moderate (|r| ≥ .4)
Moderate (r2 ≥ .16 or 16%)
Strong (|r| ≥ .8)
Strong (r2 ≥ .64 or 64%)


ACES (Adverse Childhood Experiences) -> Psychological symptoms
Word exposure frequency and elaboration of word processing in incidental vocab learning -> incidental vocabulary acquisition and retention through extensive reading
The user's tech literacy or tech-savviness, overall product quality (design, build, execution, etc.), and many more -> User experience or user satisfaction of an EdTech product
Student's participation -> Student's sense of belonging
Grade point average -> Success in first year of college


xi: IV data point for subject i
yi: DV data point for subject i
yi: Expected/predicted value for subject i (i.e., the regression line)

𝛽0: Intercept (Constant)
𝛽1: Slope (How much DV increases as IV increases by 1 unit)


One statistician movie fan decided to use statistics to study the movie ratings in his favorite movie guide, Movie and Video Guide (1996), by Leonard Maltin. Maltin rates movies on a one-star to four-star system, in increments of half-stars, with higher numbers being better. The guide also includes additional information on each film. The statistician used a random number generator to select a simple random sample of 100 movies rated by the Guide.
Rating:
Maltin rating (range is 1 to 4, in steps of 0.5)
Length:
Running time (in minutes)
Year:
Year the movie was released
Cast:
Number of case members listed in the guide
Origin:
Country (0 = USA, 1 = International)


Finding b0 and b1 (regression coefficients) for the regression line:

Best estimates for b's are the ones that provide minimal error over any other collection of b's. Working with the squared values, our goal is to find estimate b0 and b1 to minimize the error sum of squares:
SSE =
The optimal solution:
b0 = y-hat - b1x-bar
Regression line goes through both means of x and y!
The slope is determined by the correlation between x and y with a scale of y per change in x.


Analyze -> Regression -> Linear
Drag Outcome variable into the 'Dependent' box
Drag the Predictor variable into the 'Block 1 of 1' box
In the Statistics menu, select Estimates, Confidence Intervals, Model Fit, and Descriptive.

The default SPSS output has 3 sections:
Model Summary (How much variance in DV is explained by the model)
ANOVA Table (Model significance)
Regression Coefficients (Equation for the regression line)


Total variability (variance) in DV is partitioned into two parts:
What we can explain by the model (regression)
What we still cannot explain (error)
Regression sum of squares (SSR)
Error Sum of Squares (SSE)
Total Sum of Squares (SSTO)
SSTO = SSR + SSE
SSR, SSE, and SSTO are available in the ANOVA table


R2 indicates the proportion of variance in DV explained (accounted for) by the model, which can be considered the overall model fit.
R2 = (SSR) ÷ (SSTO) = 1 - (SSE ÷ SSTO) = (Multiple R)2
In SLR, R2 equals the square of the Pearson correlation between x and y
Multiple R is the correlation between yi and y-hati (always positive)
In SLR, Multiple R = | rxy |



Recall Pearson r = .318 (weak to moderate positive)
Multiple R = .318 (weak to moderate relationship)
R2 = .101, indicating 10.1% of variance in movie rating can be explained by running time.



Recall Pearson r = -. 148 (weak negative)
Multiple R = .148 (weak relationship)
R2 = .022, indicating only 2.2% of variance in movie rating can be explained by the year a movie was released.


Omnibus:
Comprising several items
"Congress passed an omnibus anticrime package."
The omnibus test is used to evaluate the significance of overall regression model. Statistics used to conduct the omnibus test are available in the ANOVA table.
Many different (equivalent) ways to represent the omnibus test, but they are asking the same question:
Is the regression model good enough to be used to explain/predict DV?
Since we are comparing variances (SSR and SSE), the sample statistics is compared to a critical F statistics, given the significance level (usually α=. 05). General idea:
Large observed F means much variance in DV can be explained by the model (desired)!


H0: β1 = 0
H1: β1 ≠ 0
H0: y-hat = y-bar
H1: y-hat = b0 +b1x (DV cannot be predicted by model)
H0: ρ = 0 (ρ is the population correlation between model and data, estimated by Multiple R)
H1: ρ > 0
H0: ρ2 = 0
H1: ρ2 > 0




Compare Fobs to the critical F(1, n -2)
Reject H0 if Fobs > F(1, n -2)
Alternatively, reject H0 if p < α
For APA style writing, make sure you report the F statistic along with both degrees of freedom and the p-value.



SSR = 4.918
SSE = 43.609
Fobs = MSR / MSE = (SSR / 1) / (SSE / n - 2) = (4.918 / 1) / (43.609 / 98) = 11.052
Since p = .001, reject H0 (significant model/predictor)
Report F (1, 98) = 11.052, p = .001
Can also check R2 = (SSR) / (SSTO) = 4.918 / 48.528 = .101



SSR = 1.057
SSE = 47.471
Fobs = MSR / MSE = (SSR / 1) / (SSE / n - 2) = (1.057 / 1) / (47.471 / 98) = 2.182
Since p = .143, cannot reject H0 (model/predictor not significant)
Report F (1, 98) = 2.182, p = .143
Can also check R2 = (SSR) / (SSTO) = 1.057 / 48.528 = .022

item.title: Testing for Normality
item.description:
An assessment of the normality of data is a prerequisite for many statistical tests because normal data is an underlying assumption in parametric testing.


SPSS allows you to test all of these procedures within Explore command. The Explore command can be used in isolation if you are testing normality in one group or splitting your dataset into one or more groups. If you have 2 or more categorical, independent variables, the Explore command on its own is not enough and you will have to use the Split File command also.


Click Analyze -> Descriptives -> Explore

Transfer the variable that needs to be tested for normality into the Dependent List box.
Click on Statistics. Leave Descriptives selected.
Click the Plots. Select Factor Levels Together under Boxplots. Select Stem-and-Leaf under Descriptive. Select Normality Plots with Tests.


When testing for normality, we are mainly interested in the Tests of Normality table and the Normal Q-Q Plots, our numerical and graphical methods to test for the normality of data, respectively.



The above table presents the results from two well-known tests of normality, namely the Kolmogorov-Smirnov Test and the Shapiro-Wilk. The Shapiro-Wilk Test is more appropriate for small sample sizes (<50 samples), but can also handle sample sizes as large as 2000.
If the Sig. value of the Shapiro-Wilk Test is greater than p = .05, the data is normal. If it is below 0.05, the data significantly deviate from a normal distribution.



In order to determine normality graphically, we can use the output of a normal P-P plot. If the data are normally distributed, the data points will be close to the diagonal line. If the data points stray from the line in an obvious non-linear fashion, the data are not normally distributed.
If the points are generally along the diagonal, the assumption is met.
If you are at all unsure of being able to correctly interpret the graph, rely on the numeric methods instead because it can take a fair bit of experience to correctly judge the normality of data based on plots.



If the histogram is approximately normal, the assumption is met.
The distribution curve is normal/bell shaped.


The assumption is met if the skewness and kurtosis is between +2 and -2.


The Explore command on its own cannot separate the dependent variable into groups based on not one but two or more independent variables. However, we can perform this feat by using the Split File command.

Click Data -> Split File
Click Organize Output by Groups. Transfer the independent variables you wish to categorize the dependent variable on into the Groups Based On box.
Proceed as above.

item.title: Testing Linearity
item.description:
The relationship between the Dependent Variable and each Independent Variable is linear.

How to Check
Use scatterplots to visualize relationships.
Click Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot.
Click Simple Scatter. Click Define.
Move your Dependent Variable (Outcome) to the Y-Axis. Move your Independent Variable (Predictor) to the X-Axis
If the scatterplot is approximately linear, the assumption is met.

Example
Plot house price against square footage to see if the relationship linear.
Solution
If not linear, apply transformations (e.g., log, square root)

Observations are independent of each other (no Autocorrelation)
How to Check
Use the Durbin-Watson test.
If the Durbin-Watson test falls within the range of 1.5 - 2.5, the assumption is met.
Examples

For this example, we'll say 1.482 is close enough to 1.5 and the assumption is met.
Ensure house prices are not influenced by neighboring houses.
