item.title: Covariate
item.description:
A covariate is an Independent Variable that is not the primary focus of your research but is included in the analysis because it might influence the Dependent Variable. In other words, it is a variable that you control for to help isolate the effect of your main Independent Variable(s).



Covariates are used to adjust for variables that might confound the relationship between your main predictors and the outcome. For example, if you're studying the effect of a new teaching method on exam scores, you might include prior GPA as a covariate to account for baseline academic ability.


By accounting for variability in the dependent variable that is due to covariates, you can reduce the error variance. This improves the precision of your estimates and increases the statistical power of your tests.


Including covariates can help provide a clearer picture of the relationship between your primary variables of interest and the outcome, leading to more accurate and interpretable results.


In analyses like ANCOVA (Analysis of Covariance), covariates are used to adjust the means of the groups so that comparisons are made at a common level of the covariate.


Imagine you're evaluating the effectiveness of a training program (the primary independent variable) on job performance (the dependent variable). However, work experience (the covariate) might also affect job performance. By including work experience as a covariate, you control for its effect, allowing you to more accurately determine the impact of the training program on job performance.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Independence of Observations
item.description:
Each observation in one group must be independent of observations in the other group.
Participants should not belong to both groups.
There should be no pairing between observations.
Measurements should not be influenced by external factors.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Independent Samples T-Test
item.description:
The independent samples t-test is used to compare the means of two independent groups to determine whether there is a significant difference between them.
It is appropriate when you have one Categorical Independent Variable with two groups (e.g., male vs. Female) and one Continuous Dependent Variable (e.g., test scores). The Null Hypothesis assumes that there is no difference between the group means.



Each observation in one group must be independent of observations in the other group.
Participants should not belong to both groups.
There should be no pairing between observations.
Measurements should not be influenced by external factors.


There is no direct statistical test for independence in SPSS.
Ensure the study design guarantees independence (e.g., random assignment or naturally occurring groups like male/female).


The dependent variable should be approximately normally distributed within each group. The t-test is fairly robust to violations of normality if sample sizes are equal and large (e.g., n ≥ 30 per group), but severe Skewness or Outliers can affect results.



Click Analyze > Descriptive Statistics > Explore
Move your Dependent Variable to the 'Dependent List'.
Move your Independent Variable to 'Factor List'.
Click Plots, check Normality Plots with Tests, and click Continue.
Click OK.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: MANOVA (Multivariate Analysis of Variance)
item.description:
Tests for differences in multiple DV s simultaneously across groups.


Comparing groups on both exam scores and project grades.




Analyze > General Linear Model > Multivariate
Move multiple DV s (e.g., exam scores, project grades) to the Dependent Variables box.
Place the group variable in the Fixed Factor(s) box.
Click OK.




Interpretation: A p-value near 0.045 indicates caution. If p-value were below 0.001, the assumption would be clearly violated. When near threshold, consider robust multivariate tests (e.g., Pillai's Trace).



Interpretation: Both tests show significance (p = 0.003), indicating a multivariate effect of group on the combined DV s.


A MANOVA was performed to assess group differences on exam scores and project grades. The multivariate tests indicated a significant effect of group, Wilks’ Λ = .73, F(4,114) = 4.21, p = .003. Follow-up univariate ANOVAs revealed significant differences for exam scores (F(2,57) = …, p = …) and project grades (F(2,57) = …, p = …). Box’s M test was marginal, M = 12.45, p = .045, warranting cautious interpretation.
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Moderation
item.description:
Moderation occurs when the strength or direction of the relationship between an Independent Variable and a Dependent Variable changes depending on the level of a third variable, known as a Moderator. In other words, the moderator influences how, or under what conditions, the IV affects the DV.


Helps determine under what conditions or for whom an effect holds true.


Imagine you are studying the impact of a training program (IV) on job performance (DV). However, you hypothesize that this relationship differs based on work experience (moderator). For individuals with high work experience, the training might have a stronger (or weaker) effect on performance compared to those with low work experience. In this case, work experience moderates the effect of training on job performance.


When conducting moderation analysis (typically through Multiple Regression with an interaction term). Several assumptions should be met:


The relationship between predictors (including the interaction term) and the DV should be linear.



Click Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot
Choose 'Simple Scatter' and click Define
Plot the DV on the Y-axis and each predictor (and, if possible, the interaction term) on the X-axis.
Look for a straight-line relationship between each predictor and the DV.


Run your Regression Analysis
Analyze > Regression > Linear
In the Linear Regression dialog, click Plots.
Move the standardized predicted values on the X box and standardized residuals to the Y box.
Click Continue and then OK.
Check the plot for a random scatter (no obvious patterns or curves) which supports the linearity assumption.


The variance of residuals should be consistent across levels of the predictors.



Use the same plot created for checking linearity.
Look for a consistent spread of residuals across all predicted values (no funnel shape or systematic change in spread).


You can also use tests like the Breusch-Pagan test in SPSS (via additional syntax or plugins) if a more formal assessment is needed.


Residuals from the regression should be approximately normally distributed.



After running your regression, save the standardized residuals.
Go to Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Histogram and plot the residuals.
The histogram should show a bell-shaped curve.


In the regression dialog (Analyze > Regression > Linear), Click Plots.
Add a Normal Q-Q plot by moving the standardized residuals to the Y box.
A Q-Q plot where the points closely follow the diagonal line indicates that the residuals are normally distributed.


The observations should be independent of each other (i.e., no Autocorrelation)



Ensure that your data collection method supports the assumption of independence (e.g., participants are sampled independently)


When running the regression (Analyze > Regression > Linear), SPSS outputs the Durbin-Watson statistic.
A value around 2 suggests that the residuals are independent. Values deviating substantially from 2 indicate potential issues.


Predictor variables (including the interaction term) should not be too highly correlated.



Ensure that variables are centered (or standardized) to reduce Multicollinearity when creating interaction terms.


Multiply the centered IV and Moderator.


Click Analyze > Regression > PROCESS v
Enter the IV, moderator, and the interaction term as Predictor s.
For moderation analysis, use Model 1.
PROCESS automatically creates the interaction term (Training x Work Experience)
If your variables are continuous, it is often recommended to center them first (or use PROCESS options that center them automatically)



IV and Moderator Coefficients:
These represent the effect of the IV and moderator on the DV when the other variable is at its mean (if centered).


Interaction Coefficient (IV × Moderator):
Significance: A statistically significant interaction term (typically p < .05) indicates that the effect of the IV on the DV changes depending on the level of the moderator.
Interpretation: If the coefficient is positive, as the moderator increases, the effect of the IV on the DV becomes stronger (or more positive); if negative, the effect weakens (or becomes more negative).


Purpose: To determine how the IV-DV relationship varies at specific values of the moderator (e.g., at the mean, one standard deviation above, and one standard deviation below the mean).
Output: SPSS (via PROCESS) often provides these slopes along with their confidence intervals and p-values.


Suppose you get the following (hypothetical) output:
IV (Training): b = 0.30, SE = 0.10, p = .003
Moderator (Work Experience): b = 0.20, SE = 0.08, p =.012
Interaction (Training × Work Experience): b = 0.15, SE = 0.05, p = .002


The significant interaction (p = .002) suggests that the effect of training on job performance depends on work experience.
A simple slopes analysis might reveal that for individuals with high work experience (e.g., +1 SD), the effect of training on performance is stronger (say, b=0.45b = 0.45b=0.45) compared to those with low work experience (e.g., -1 SD, b=0.15b = 0.15b=0.15).


Below is an example of how you might report your findings in APA style:
A moderation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 1) to examine whether work experience moderated the relationship between training and job performance. The results indicated a significant interaction between training and work experience, b = 0.15, SE = 0.05, p = .002, suggesting that the effect of training on job performance varied as a function of work experience. Simple slopes analysis revealed that the relationship between training and job performance was stronger for participants with high work experience (b = 0.45, p < .001) compared to those with low work experience (b = 0.15, p = .045). These findings indicate that work experience significantly moderates the relationship between training and job performance.

item.title: 3. EFT
item.description:
Collaborative alliance: models and provides a secure base.
Emotion is primary in organizing attachment behaviora and the ways self and other are experienced in intimate relationships (primary and secondary emotions)
Attachments are adaptive and healthy
Problems are maintained by interaction patterns and by the dominant organization of emotional experience of each partner.
Change occurs through new emotional experience in the context of attachment-salient interactions as they occur in session. (make it important to attachment, example: new parents, partners are not used to the difference in attachment and time spent in the relationship)
The 'client' is the relationship.

Gas lighting is an attachment injury


Creation of new cycles of secure bonding, which offer an antidote to negative cycles and positively redefine the nature of the relationship.


Create a safe, collaborative alliance.
Access, reformulate, and expand the emotional responses that guide the couple's interaction.
Restructure those interactions in the direction of the accessibility and responsiveness that builds, secure lasting bonds.



Step 1: Identify the relational conflict issues.
Step 2: Identify the negative interaction cycle
Step 3: Access the unacknowledged attachment oriented emotions underlying the interaction cycle.
Step 4: Reframe the problem in terms of the cycle, underlying emotions that accompany it, and attachment vulnerabilities and needs.


Step 5: Promote identification with disowned attachment needs and aspects of self.
Step 6: Promote each partner's acceptance of the other's experience.
Step 7: Facilitate the expression of needs and wants to restructure the interactional based on new understandings and to create bonding events.


Step 8: Facilitate the emergence of new solutions to old problems.
Step 9: Consolidate new positions and cycles of attachment behavior.


Alliance
Commenting on the process, and interpreting with attachment language to draw out each partner's emotional experience.
Enactments with expanded emotional experiences.
Commenting on the experiences so that they can be integrated.
How can we help you process when you get loud?

item.title: 4. Gottman
item.description:
Most relationship conflict is not solvable, but perpetual based on personality characteristics of the partners. This can lead to grid lock.
Gridlock conflict is about the escalation of negative affect reciprocity
To get 'dialogue' with a perpetual issue, you have to understand the existential nature of it or the 'dreams within conflict'
Building positivity during non-conflict and conflict is essential for lasting change.
Friendship processes control the effectiveness and thresholds of the repair of problematic interaction.
Couple's construction of a 'shared meaning system' facilitates stability and happiness.
Three systems need to be understood (conflict, friendship/intimacy/positive affect, and shared meaning) need to be understood to intervene.


For Gottman, theory must provide a 'recipe' for therapeutic change


Repair:
Processing fights and regrettable incidents.
Reduce the use of the 4 Horsemen.
Gottman-Rapport Blueprint for Practice Exercise (Speaker Listener Activity) (postpone persuasion, until both partners acknowledge the others perspective and emotion to the other's satisfaction)
Problem-solving, persuasion, and compromise
Blueprint for perpetual unsolvable conflict (Dreams within conflict, one person takes a turn while the other person is listen, not trying to persuade, the objective is to reflect back what you hear)
Down-regulating negative affect with physiological soothing (biofeedback)


Get couples to notice positives and accept influence.
They are going to acknowledge their partner.


Help couples turn toward each other when bids for connection are made.
Build positive affect separately from helping to decrease ineffective conflict.
'Savor' positive affect
5 to 1 ratio vs. 0.8 to 1


Emotional connection during everyday moments (build love maps, build a culture of appreciation, turn towards bids for connection, engage in emotion coaching, increase and savor positive affect)
Daily stress-reducing conversation
Build affection, good sex, romance, and passion
Process failed bods for emotional connection


Here they move to more emotion focused techniques, and theory, using a metaphor of attachment +
Use card decks to help couple members identify emotions, talk about their beliefs about emotion etc.
Encourage emotion coaching


Create shared meaning by making rituals of emotional connection intentional.
Create shared meanings by making goals and values intentional.

item.title: 6. Discernment Counseling and Divorce
item.description:
Read @dohertyHelpingCouplesBrink2017
Read Research Citations/A/@abbasiPolarizedCouplesTherapy2017
Read @allanUseEmotionallyFocused2016
Read @dohertyDiscernmentCounselingMixed2016
Read Chapter 21 of @lebowClinicalHandbookCouple2023


Emotional process
Pull couple back to the goals.
Build alliance
Educate people on how parents can maintain a relationship with their children and not to pull the children between the parents.
What is in the way of making a clear back
Establish clear and 'good enough' communication
How do you establish rules of communication? How do you negotiate when they are broken?
They need to learn to disengage from each other.
Couples that do not live together can stop talking to each other.
They need to come up with enough communication that it is enough.
The more they are fighting the more they are
Reattribution
Creating a new script
Helping the couple figure out th



Goals for Discernment Counseling:
Clarity and confidence about a direction for the marriage based on a deeper understanding of what has happened to the marriage, and each person's contributions to the problems.
Discernment counseling ends with a decision to take one of three paths:
Couple therapy
Divorce
Status Quo


Could be up to 30% of couples who come to therapy, but our models and techniques do not prepare us for these types of couples (one is leaning in the other leaning out).
These types of couples are difficult to treat because of their conflicting goals for therapy. One to say it is worth investing in the relationship and we can fix the problems, the other perhaps to prove that we have done all we can it is time to split.
Doherty believed that before trying to do any sort of couple work, these couples needed to decide if that is what they wanted.


Short term processes: 1-5 sessions
Goal is to get a deeper understanding of what has happened in the relationship and each partner's contributions to the problems.
Three paths:
Status quo
Divorce
Therapy


Couple together
One spouse separately
Summary to the other spouse
One spouse separately
Summary to the other spouse
Couple together


Not much research on Mixed-Agenda Couples couples and how to work with them. Most work suggests that Mixed-Agenda Couples couples are common (about 30%). Outcome research is sparse but suggest that these couples when treated with couple therapy are more likely to separate.
Also evidence that people going through the divorce process believe the marriage could be saved (about 26%) and are interested in reconciliation services (about 33%).
Lots of evidence of ambivalence about the divorce and the relationship.
About 66.2% of folks in the divorce process were sure they wanted the divorce, 16.5% had mixed feelings, and 9.8% would consider reconciliation.
Conclusion:
We need some way of providing services to folks considering divorce to help them with their mixed feelings and decide on a path.


100 cases evaluated
97 heterosexual couples, 3 same-sex
Married an average of 15.5 years
Highly distressed based on the DAS short form
51% had consulted a divorce attorney
Well educated
48% came based on self-referral, 34% from therapists or social service agencies, 11% from attorneys or judges.
Findings:
Average number of sessions 3.61
47% decided on path 3 (therapy), 41% separation/divorce, and 12% status quo.
Contact with a divorce attorney associated with a lower likelihood of path 3, and higher likelihood of path 2.
At follow-up, those who chose path 2:
90% were divorced or in the process, one couple reconciled, and 3 were on hold.
Those who chose path 3:
36% reconciled, 6% in process, 28% had divorced, 17% were in process of divorce, and 13% were on hold.


Ask what they understand about discernment counseling.
For the leaning-out partner:
Make sure they feel heard and that they understand the process of discernment and that it is different than couple therapy then ask if they are still seeking some sort of clarity on the process of divorce, and how confident they are in their decision.
For the leaning-in partner:
They recommend they read 'The Divorce Remedy by Michele Weiner-Davis', which provides advice for folks who have just found out their partner wants a divorce.
Recommended that you contact both partners separately for these intake conversations.


Block out 2 hours for the first session.
Meet together to ask questions, meet with each partner separately, provide summaries to the partners after each individual session, then come back together to summarize the set of sessions, therapist's impressions of the couple, then if both partners agree, schedule the second session.
Questions for both:
What happened to your marriage that's gotten you to the point where divorce is a possibility? Can you tell me what you have done to try to fix the problems in the marriage, whether on your own or with help?
What role, if any, do your children play in your decision making about the future of your relationship?
Can you tell me about a time in your relationship, since the time you met, when you felt the most connection and joy?
Questions for Leaning-Out partner (see this person first):
Tell me more about your pain and reasons for considering divorce.
(Within no more than 10 minutes) switch to a conversation about the paths.
Find out how far they have gone in formalizing divorce plans (contacted attorney, papers drawn up, etc.)
Ask them their perspective on their contributions to the problems in the marriage.
Prepare a summary statement for the other partner about something they have taken away from the individual time, then invite partner 2 in the room to hear the summary statement.
Now work with the leaning-in partner:
Help them articulate that they understand their partner's concerns and can understand why their partner might be interested in divorce.
Ask about their perspective on their own contributions to the problems in the relationship.
Help them figure out how to respond without being too anxious or withdrawing completely.
Summary statement:
Must convey the sense that the leaning-in partner understands why their partner is contemplating divorce, and some empathy for this position.
Once both people are in the room again, and the leaning-in partner has shared their summary statement, then the therapist shares their observations.
What themes have you noticed, and your perception of how they got to this place.
Couple does not have to agree on a path at the end of this session, but they may, they recommend that the couple return for at least a 2 nd discernment session before deciding, especially Path 3.


Goals:
Clarity
Confidence
More understanding
90-minute sessions:
Time together
Time separately with summaries
Time together wrap-up
Check-in:
3 goals:
Learning where each partner is in their discernment process
Reminding partners of the goals of discernment
Acoiding an open-ended invitation to talk about the relationship problems.
Leaning-out partner:
Move to help them see their contributions
Leaning-In partner:
Move to help them develop a plan for change
Discernment is not the same for both partners, leaning in partner carries a bigger burden of leadership about what they may need to change in order for the marriage to be more viable.
Summaries should become more self-revealing and intense, therapist feedback can also be more in-depth in terms of positives and negatives.


Need to prepare partners for the work that will need to be done in therapy.
If you are going to be the couple therapist have a transition session possibly using the Agreement to Pursue Reconciliation Form (pg. 103).
Generate personal agendas for change (pg. 105) and have them share with each other.


Explore the divorce decision:
Freedom
Relief
Painful letting go
Deal with the emotional fall-out of the decision
Prepare couple for a constructive divorce process in their interactions with each other, in their dealings with their children, and in choosing professional assistance.
Offer more sessions about a constructive divorce process.
Monitor the emotions and although emphasizing with each partner interrupt intense emotional outpourings from leaning-in partner, keep things as calm as possible.
In your summary, state any commonalities you have heard about their divorce hopes and dreams for their children, co-parenting, and their interest in mediation and collaborative divorce processes.


Why couples may choose this path:
Leaning-out partner still can't decide and leaning-in partner is still leaning-in.
The couple may have gotten enough from the session (relief, able to talk more calmly about the issues, feel heard for the first time, etc.) so they feel ready to continue the relationship without more therapy.
It may also be it doesn't seem like the right time for a big change in their lives (considering their children or other situations).
Some believe that situations that are impinging on their relationship might change so they decide to wait it out.

item.title: 7. Sexual Disorders and Therapy
item.description:
Read Weeks et al., (2020) (Chapters 2-5)
“The Sexual Response Cycle.png” could not be found.
Masters & Johnson's EPOR Model:
Excitement
The first phase in the EPOR model, in which the first physical changes of sexual arousal occur.
Vasocongestion
The swelling of erectile tissues due to increased blood flow during sexual arousal.
Male:
“Male EPOC Cycle.png” could not be found.
Female:
“Female Arousal State.png” could not be found.
Sex Flush:
A darkening or reddening of the skin of the chest area that occurs in some people during sexual arousal.
Plateau:
The second phase in the EPOR model during which sexual arousal levels off (reaches a plateau) and remains at an elevated level of excitement.
Tenting
A widening of the inner two-thirds of the vaginal during sexual arousal.
Orgasm
Resolution



A heterogeneous group of disorders that are characterized by:
A clinically significant disturbance in a person's ability to respond sexually or experience sexual pleasure
Three female sexual disorders:
Female Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder
Female Orgasmic Disorder
Genito-Pelvic Pain/Penetration Disorder (GPPPD)
Four Male Sexual Disorders:
Male Hypoactive Sexual Desire Disorder
Erectile Disorder
Delayed Ejaculation
Premature Ejaculation
Other categories:
Substance/Medication-Induced Sexual Dysfunction
Other Specified Sexual Dysfunction (includes distressing sexual symptoms but does not meet the criteria for a specific disorder with reasons why)
Unspecified Sexual Dysfunction (same as above with no reasons why)
Specifiers
Lifelong vs. Acquired
Generalized vs. Situational
Severity of Distress


Individual/Biological
Individual/Psychological
The Dyadic Relationship
Family of Origin Influences
Contextual Factors (Society/Culture/History/Religion etc.)


Female Sexual Interest (Arousal Disorder):
Absent/reduced interest in sexual activity
Absent/reduced sexual/erotic thoughts or fantasies
No/reduced initiation of sexual activity
Typically unreceptive to a partner's attempt to initiate
Absent/reduced sexual excitement/pleasure during sexual activity in all or almost all (75%-100%) sexual encounters
Absent/reduced sexual interest/arousal in response to any internal or external sexual/erotic cues
Absent/reduced genital or non-genital sensations during sexual activity in all or almost all (75%-100%) sexual encounters
The changes to this definition (from previous DSM version) was in recognition that sexual desire is less spontaneous for women than men, and more related to contextual and relational variables. Authors believed that this helped to depathologize women for the lack of so-called spontaneous desire, especially because these symptoms need to be present for at least 6 months to render this diagnosis.
Female Orgasmic Disorder:
Marked delay in, marked infrequency of or absence of orgasm or markedly reduced intensity or orgasmic sensations (essential to assess for levels of distress around this).
Genito-Pelvic Pain (Penetration Disorder) (GPPPD):
Vaginal penetration during intercourse
Marked vulvovaginal or pelvic pain during vaginal intercourse or penetration attempts marked fear or anxiety about vulvovaginal or pelvic pain in anticipation of, during, or as a result of vaginal penetration.
Marked tensing or tightening of the pelvic floor muscles during attempted vaginal penetration.
Important to explore all the factors that may be at play here (physiological, cognitive, emotional, behavioral and interpersonal, including past trauma).


Male Hypoactive Sexual Desire Disorder:
Male must present with persistently or recurrent deficient (or absent) sexual/erotic thoughts or fantasies and desire for sexual activity.
Not much known about this, and it rarely the primary presenting concern.
Erectile Disorder (at least one of 3)
Marked difficulty in obtaining an erection during sexual activity.
Marked difficulty in maintainig an erection until completion of sexual activity.
Marked decrease in erectil rigidity.
Prevalence increases with age and other disease states. Medical screenings are essential when working with clients with this condition.
Premature Ejaculation
A persistent or recurrent pattern of ejaculation occurring during partnered sexual activity within approximately 1-minute following vaginal penetration and before the individual wishes it.
Symptoms of erectile disfunction and premature ejaculation are often co-occurring. Performance anxiety is often found with either disorder.
Delayed Ejaculation:
Marked delay in ejaculation or marked infrequency or absence of ejaculation and the individual must desire ejaculation.


It is probably more common to see couples who do not have diagnosable disorders but have complaints about the sexual aspects of their relationships.
The most common problem is desire discrepancy.
Some conditions are currently being considered for inclusion in the DSM:
Sexual Compulsivity, Addition, or Hypersexuality
Gender Non-Conformity (DSM-5 less restrictive, some things that would automatically mean a disorder are now only a disorder if there is distress or impairment around the activity)
Persistent Genital Arousal Disorder (for females, unrelenting genital arousal that does not diminish with orgasm)
Sexual Aversion Disorder (no longer listed as a sexual disorder, but as a phobia)
Male Dyspareunia (men who had persistent pain with sexual activity; could be as simple as an infection, or more complex floor abnormalities).


More comprehensive than talking about symptoms alone. Include the following:
The couple's perception of the problem (s)
Current baseline of individual and relational functioning
Physical status of each partner
The couple's expectations or goals for the treatment
Realistic treatment goals
Level of sexual desire of each partner
Perceived degree of sexual satisfaction
Level of distress experienced because of the sexual problem
Impact on the intimate relationship
The functions of sex in the relationship
Get a sexual history from each partner (can be questionnaires or through interviewing, authors suggest conjoint interviewing to develop alliance and watch the process, they recommend flexible use of conjoint and individual sessions).
Authors recommend that therapists understand their own sexual so that they can avoid inadvertently or overtly shaming. Use more open-ended questions and be careful about the words you use (i.e., have you been unfaithful? Vs. Do you have intimate relations with others in addition to your primary partner?)
Adopt a stance of both never assuming and always assuming:
Never assume a client's sexual orientation
Always assume that everyone does everything
Never assume that clients are educated about all aspects of sexuality
Book provides lots of suggestions for how to ask questions to get at specific diagnoses and questions to ask when taking a sexual history.


Focus on gender, romantic love, attachment, intimacy, communication, gender orientation, and other themes associated with sexuality (provides questions to ask to complete the genogram)
Beliefs about being a man or a woman
Family patterns of relationships
Couple relationship patterns (affairs, divorces, abandonment, loyalty and sacrifice)
Family impact on current gender behavior
Peer expectations
Cultural expectations


Assessment in sex therapy is essential for determining a treatment plan (like all therapy)
There are formal assessment instruments but they were mostly designed for previous DSM versions, not the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) -5, they can still be used but may not be as useful for diagnosis.
Behavioral assessment (i.e., similar to BCT)
Physiological measures (scores for respondent's perceptions of satisfaction with, or pain during phases of the sexual response cycle).


Relationship issues vs. Sexual disorders (need to determine which is a priority for the couple)
Thorough Assessment
Collaborate on treatment planning
Is the couple ready?

Weeks et al., (Chapters 1, 6-13, and 16)
These techniques are not for the usual clients with sexual discrepancies (i.e., one client has a higher libido than the other). It is for individuals that struggle with sexual disorders/dysfunctions.



Therapist directed or structured.
You can collaborate, but the therapist is not coming up with their own examples.
Related to practicing activities learned in sessions and other behaviors that are carefully crafted and explained during the session.
Expected to facilitate a therapeutic effect.
Need to be practical.
Practiced in small increments toward a goal (typically not erection, penetration, or orgasm).
Major goal is to reduce anxiety and reinforce new behavior.
Need to be relevant to the issues, and within the ability of the client or couple.
Make the assignment (perhaps in writing as well) and then work with the couple and what they think about the assignment, ay questions they have and any fears ,, they have about starting the assignment.
Collaborate so that the clients are invested and the assignment is tailored to them.
Negotiate the schedule, who initiates, and make sure they clearly understand what they are supposed to do.
Process the assignment the next session, what worked, what didn't, etc. Access effort.


Most effective evidence-based practices in combination with psychotherapy. For sex therapy, it includes information about sexual functioning, sexual disorders, sexual orientation, gender diversity, STI’s.
Comes in many forms (helps dispel myths, normalize, and inform)
Bibliotherapy (books, internet-based material, TV shows, or other forms of media)
Ensure to read, listen, and watch to the examples you will be giving to clients.
Need to gauge the clients' tastes and tolerance in using these resources.


Incorporates psychoeducation about the sexual response and a series of incremental physical exercises performed outside of the therapeutic setting.
Viewed as a form of desensitization intended to promote relaxation, communication and attention to physical sensations of touch, and the physical emotional connections between partners.
Combined with mindfulness (being present in the moment, not thinking about past or future; making no judgements, not spectating). Authors use a more systemic approach to sensate focus then originally designed. They include both partners, and create smaller increments of behaviors moving toward genital touch then Masters and Johnson.


9 functions of sensate focus:
Become more aware of sensations
Focus solely on one's own needs for pleasure
Communicate sensual and sexual needs, wishes and desires
Increase awareness of partner's sensual and sexual needs
Expand the repertoire of intimate touch, sensual and sexual behaviors
Learn to appreciate foreplay or touch as an end in itself rather than a means to an end
Create positive relationship experiences
Build sexual desire
Enhance the level of love, caring, commitment, intimacy cooperation, and sexual interest in the relationship


Describe what is involved, noting each partner's reaction (see questions on page 183)
What is 'good enough' sex?
Go slowly if one or both partners express hesitation or ambivalence or simple refusal.


Tailored to the specific needs of the couple.
The 'goal' of the exercise is the touch and the experience of the sensations, not erection, orgasm, penetration, etc.
Specific assignments should occur weekly, so assignments can be reviewed and revised. Remind couples that this is a chance to rebuild physical and emotional intimacy and there is no hurry.
Couple is instructed to avoid intercourse and any activity that is sexual. The idea is to create a non-demand atmosphere. (reducing performance anxiety, increasing pleasurable encounters).
Create a sensual environment.
Partners are both givers and receivers (regardless of the Identified Patient (IP))
Gradually build, first touch in general, no genital touch, with and without clothing to focus on sensations from touch, coach them to talk about what they like and what they want/need. During each session the giver listens to the receiver. The receiver progresses to being present (mindful) during the exercise only.
Review the assignment at the next session (questions on page 187)
Once the couple is comfortable with nonsexual touch, move to erotic and genital touch, again in small increments. The goal is for the couple to experience sexual stimulation as a goal in itself.
If desired, then the couple can move to intercourse (no pressure). This can also be done in gradual steps.
Use exercises listed as examples for specific disorders.


Using the Miracle Question to distill down the preferred narrative.
CBCT is a good example to help couples. Couples need to focus on emotions rather than logical thoughts that keep them stuck in their cycle.



Sexual Ignorance:
Performance-based, goal-oriented model of normal is damaging to sexual intimacy.
Sexual Mythology:
Misguided beliefs, misconceptions, and distortions that promote unrealistic standards and rigid expectations.
Faculty Cognitions:
These can be engrained and automatic. They then can interfere with sexual desire, and limit a range of sexual behaviors (i.e., masturbation).
Sexual guilt, anxiety, and shame


Counter Faulty Beliefs
Psychoeducation
CBT Techniques
Dealing with Intimacy Fears
Underlying and unconscious fears of intimacy can complicate sex therapy (do couple work first)
Distance regulation (fears of rejection/abandonment, dependency, anger, emotion, losing control).


Sex therapists need to be collaborators with medical practitioners in the treatment of medically related sexual issues and cognitive disabilities
Physical Illness:
Sexual functioning involves many body systems. Thus, illness can impact sexual functioning. It is best to research the illness and what body systems are impacted by it (it is systemic) before deciding on a course of treatment.
Neurological Ailments (affect physical)

item.title: The Use of Emotionally Focused Therapy with Separated or Divorced Couples
item.description:
Bibliography:
Type: Journal Article
Title: The Use of Emotionally Focused Therapy with Separated or Divorced Couples Le recours à la thérapie centrée sur l’émotion auprès des couples séparés ou divorcés,
Author: Allan, Robert;

Couples with children who are separated or divorced need to develop a plan for coparenting and the lifelong shared tasks of childrearing. While legally informed programs can offer mediation, these services can miss the underlying conflict that continues to plague postseparation couple relationships and, more importantly, their children. Divorce is a process with multiple transitions for a family, and the couples who separate or divorce may have a history of negative communication patterns that have long corroded their relationship. There is a need to develop a new coparenting relationship that can serve as a foundation for the long-term. The research literature varies in understanding the impact of divorce on children, but there is consistent agreement that parental conflict does affect child maladjustment. Emotionally focused therapy (EFT) is one effective means of working with a couple who are separated or divorced. EFT is an empirically supported couples’ treatment that was developed from attachment, emotion, and systems theories. This article explores the use of Stage 1 of EFT for couples who are separated or divorced, using a case example to further illustrate the model.

Protective Factors for Adverse Childhood Experiences: The Role of Emotion Regulation and Attachment
item.description:
Bibliography: Tanner, M. A., & Francis, S. E. (2025). Protective Factors for Adverse Childhood Experiences: The Role of Emotion Regulation and Attachment. Journal of Child and Family Studies. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10826-024-02989-7
Type: Journal Article
Title: Protective Factors for Adverse Childhood Experiences: The Role of Emotion Regulation and Attachment,
Author: Tanner, Mackenzie A.; Francis, Sarah E.;
Journal: Journal of Child and Family Studies,
Year: 2025
DOI: 10.1007/s10826-024-02989-7
ISSN: 1062-1024, 1573-2843

Adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) have a powerful impact on adolescents’ development. The greater the number of stressful life events experienced, the more likely adolescents are to experience internalizing symptoms, such as anxiety. Due to the negative effects of early adversity, it is essential that research examine which protective factors might mitigate this relationship, such as emotion regulation (ER) and attachment. In the current study, the researchers examined the relationships between ACEs, ER, attachment, and anxiety among adolescents. We hypothesized that ER would mediate the relationship between ACEs and anxiety and attachment would moderate the relationship between ACEs and ER within the mediation model. A sample of adolescents (n = 105) completed measures of adolescent anxiety, ACEs, ER, and attachment. Using the PROCESS macro, a moderated mediation model was analyzed. Mother and father attachment moderated the mediation of difﬁculties in ER on ACEs and anxiety, suggesting that mean levels of mother and higher levels of father attachment function as a mechanism that strengthens the relationship between early negative life events and current anxiety. These ﬁndings suggest that the mother/father attachment relationship for adolescents might be of particular importance for youth who have experienced adverse life experiences and have trouble regulating their emotions.

Type: Book
Title: Mastering competencies in family therapy: a practical approach to theory and clinical case documentation
Author: Gehart, Diane R.
Publisher: Cengage Learning
Location: San Francisco, CA
Year: 2017
ISBN: 978-1-305-94327-8


Local Library: Zotero




Theory:
Describe the following elements of the Satir model and emotionally focused therapy:
Process of therapy
Therapeutic relationship
Case conceptualization
Goal setting
Interventions
Case Conceptualization and Treatment Plan
Complete a theory-specific case conceptualizations and treatment plans for Satir family therapy and emotionally focused couples therapy using templates that are provided.
Research
Provide an overview of significant research findings for Satir family therapy and emotionally focused couples therapy.
Diversity
Analyze strengths, limitations, and appropriate applications for using experiential approaches with clients in relation to their social location/diverse identities, including but not limited to ethnic, racial, and/or sexual/gender identity diversity.
Cross-Theoretical Comparison
Compare how experiential therapies utilize interpersonal patterns (IPs) with other approaches described in this book.


Integrating systemic theory with humanism, experiential family therapists are noted for their warmth and direct emotional engagement with clients. These approaches include:
The Satir Model
Emotionally Focused Therapy (EFT)
EFT integrates experiential, systemic, and attachment theories to help couples and families create emotional safety to foster wellness interaction patterns.
Symbolic-Experiential Family Therapy
Carl Whitaker developed symbolic-experiential therapy, which focuses on symbolic meanings and emotional exchanges within the family using a balance of warmth and confrontation to promote change.



Whereas systemic, strategic, structural, and cognitive-behavioral family therapists primarily track behavior interaction sequences, experiential family therapists focus more on the affective or emotional layer of those same interactions - while still attending to behavior and cognitions.
Assessment and interventions target the emotional exchanges between family members and significant others in relation to the presenting problem.


Experiential family therapists use warmth and empathy in building relationships with clients.
Therapists use themselves - their personhood - to make this strong affective connection with clients.
This approach creates a sense of safety that allows clients to explore areas of emotional vulnerability.


Experiential family therapies affress individual and family concerns as distinct sets of problems.
In contrast, systemic, structural, and integenerational therapies conceptualize individual systems as part of the family system. They assume that individual symptoms will resolve if the family system is treated.




She began her career in family therapy at the Mental Research Institute (MRI) working alongside Jay Haley, Paul Watzlawick, Richard Fisch, and the other leading family therapists in Palo Alto.
Her therapy focused on fostering individual growth as well as improving family interactions.



The Communication Stances in the Satir model offer a clinician an efficient and effect means of conceptualizing how best to communicate and interact with the client.
She describes 4 communication survival or coping stances:
Blaming (Blamer)
Placating (Placator)
Super-Reasonable (Computer)
Irrelevant (Distractor)
These stances develop in childhoodand reveal how a person communicates under stress, especially when they do not feel emotionally safe in intimate relationships.
A person can use more than one, but typically a person uses one style predominantly.
Each stance acknowledges or minimizes three basic realities:
Self
Other
Context
The goal is to move people toward Congruent (Congruence) communication in which they respectfully balance the needs of self and others while responding appropriately within and acknowledging the context .



Each survival stance minimizes one or more essential part of the total picture.



Because placatory have people-pleasing tendencies, therapists use less directive therapy methods, such as multiple choice questions and open-ended reflections, to require them to voice their opinion and take a stand.
Therapists should carefully avoid giving opinions, making it seem that they have an opinion, or offering too much personal information.
Clients will use this type of information to know what parts of themselves to hide and what parts to foreground to gain therapist approval.
Research indicates that some clients make up things to give the impression that therapy is progressing.
Not until the placator regularly and openly disagrees with the therapist has rapport been established.



Therapists can best connect with those who blame through addressing their expectations. The goal often is to increase blamers' awareness of others' thoughts and feelings and help them learn how to communicate their personal perspectives in ways that are respectful of others.
With these clients, direct confrontation often strengthens the therapeutic relationship.
Blamers generally prefer more upfront and direct communication than is generally tolerated in polite society.



When working with those who use a super-reasonable stance, logic and rules reign supreme.
Since these clients avoid all emotions, therapists might best engage them by starting with their bodily reactions and expectations before moving onto feelings.
The goal with this stance is to help clients value the internal, subjective realities of themselves and others.



A client with the irrelevant stance creates a unique challenge for therapists because there is no consistent grounding in self, other, or context for the therapist to use in understanding and communicating with the client.
The therapist must spend time 'floating' along with the client's distractions to identify the unique 'anchors' of the client's reality that the therapist can tap into.
Bodily sensations, touch, and physical activities often work best with this client stance.
As treatment progresses, the therapist works with these clients to increase their ability to recognize the thoughts and feelings of self and others and to acknowledge the demands of context.
Progress is typically slower with those who use this stance frequently.


Virginia Satir
She began her private practice in 1951, and by 1955, she was training therapists at the Illinois Psychiatric Institute to work with families. She then joined MRI in Palo Alto.
1962 was the year she received a grant from the NIMH that provided funding to establish the first family therapy training program.


Satir uses a six-stage model of change that is based on research on Cybernetics systems conducted by Satir while at the MRI.
Her six-stage model describes how the therapy process helps families move toward a Second-Order Change in the family structure.
The model emphasizes that the therapist perturbs the system (Shaking it up and respecting its ability to naturally reorganize itself in a more useful way) rather than attempting to direct and control the system from the outside.
Even though Satir uses education and coaches clients on how to better communicate, the aim is not for clients to follow her instructions literally but rather to adapt and respond to the instructions in a way that works for their system.
The six-stages:
Status Quo
This is a state of homeostasis that includes at least one symptomatic member.
Foreign Element
May be a life crisis, tragedy, or therapeutic intervention, gets the system off balance.
Chaos
The new perspective creates a Positive Feedback loop that throws the system into a state of chaos. At this point, the 'natural' response is to feel uncomfortable, and in almost all cases the family tries to regain the Status Quo, which may or may not be possible.
Integration of New Possibilities
Eventually, the family system interprets the new information in a meaningful way; the therapist needs to be respectful of how the system uses the information and responds to therapist-client interactions, honoring and trusting the system's autonomy.
Practice
The system develops a new set of interaction patterns based on the new information.
This may or may not look like what the therapist expects, but the therapist asks two key evaluative questions:
Are the symptoms improving?
Is each person able to self-actualize and grow?
New Status Quo
This is a state of new homeostasis that does not include a symptomatic member and that allows all members to grow and flourish.
Therapy involves going through these 6 stages several times, with the discomfort and relative sense of chaos diminishing each time the client cycles through, becoming increasingly comfortable with change.



Four primary assumptions about people and therapy:
People naturally tend toward positive growth (humanistic principle).
All people possess the resources for positive growth (humanistic principle).
Every person and every thing or situation impacts and is impacted by everyone and everything else (systemic principle)
Therapy is a process that involves interaction between a therapist and a client. In this relationship, each person is responsible for themselves (systemic and humanistic principle).
These assumptions clarify the therapist's role in the process (the therapist is 'responsible for themself'), but also how the therapist believes the therapeutic process works:
Clients already possess the natural inclination toward growth and the resources for it, and it is the therapist's job to activate these tendencies.
The role of the therapist is that of a guide to the process of becoming more fully human.


Carl Rogers, a leader in humanistic, experiential therapies, based his client-centered approach on three therapist qualities:
Congruent (Congruence) or Genuineness
Accurate Empathy
Unconditional Positive Regard
These conditions are the theoretical foundations of warmth and humanity.
This quality of being, or therapeutic presnce, is difficult to define, and there are methods for systematically developing it.
The more therapists are Congruent (Congruence) - that is being able to communicate authentically while responding to the needs of both self and others - the better they can create the therapeutic warmth and humanity.


Satir describes establishing a therapeutic relationship as 'making contact,' which refers to a series of connection both within the therapist and between the therapist and client.
Making contact begins with the therapist being in contact with themselves, including all resources of the self as defined in the Self-Mandala: physical, intellectual, emotional, sensual, interactional, nutritional, contextual, and spiritual.
The therapist also prepares to meet another 'miracle,' a fellow human being.
The therapist then works to make contact with each client in the room, engaging them on 'all channels':
Mind
Body
Spirit
Open body position and congruent communication are critical.
Once the therapist has made contact with each person, the therapist works to help family members make contact with each other and ultimately with others in their broader social system.
The therapy process cannot move forward until the therapist has made contact with the client.
When contact is made, clients feel valued for who they are, regardless of their problem, and they feel free to make mistakes in the therapist's presence.
Making contact involves:
Making direct eye contact
Touching clients (e.g., shaking hands)
Sitting or standing at the same physical level so that eye contact is easy (i.e., leaning down to talk with children)
Asking each person's name and how he or she prefers to be called


Satir practitioners convey their understanding of clients' subjective, inner realities by expressing Empathy, an accurate understanding of another's emotional reality.
Clients like therapists who take their side, don't confront them, and ignore their responsibility in the problem situation. This type of validation is detrimental to therapeutic progress.
Comments that imply a client has a right to feel a certain way can also shut down the process of reflecting on the client's responsibility for their half of an interaction.
Expressing empathy emphasizes that is not wrong or right, not normal or abnormal, to feel a certain way - it is simply how the client feels and means that this is their 'truth,' at least for the moment (e.g., "It sounds as though you felt betrayed")
Honoring the client's unique experience without validating it as right or normal makes it much easier to move the client toward seeing that the other person has their unique experience that is also 'true' for that person, creating a context from which to understand how these two (or more) realities may collide and create problematic interactions.


In joining with clients, therapists instill hope that they can change and that the situation can be better, even if it seems hopeless at the moment.
Satir et al., (1991) emphasize that clients must have faith that change is possible before they can move forward with treatment.


Clients need to believe that therapy and their therapist can help them resolve their problems.
Therapists establish credibility by making a personal connection (making contact) and by being confident and competent (modeling high self-esteem).


Both family functioning and individual functioning are assessed.


Role of the Symptom in the System
Describe how the symptom maintains the family's homeostasis at an emotional level, often regulating closeness and distance (Distance Regulation; Differentiation of Self)
Family Dynamics
Identify salient dynamics
Power struggles
Parental conflict
Lack of validation
Lack of intimacy
Family Roles
Identify possible family roles.
Martyr
Victim or Helpless One
Rescuer
Good Child or Parent
Bad Child or Parent
Family Life Chronology
Describe key historical events, deaths, births, divorces, major life changes.
Survival Triad
Describe the emotional and nurturing relationships between each child and parents.


Communication Stances
Identify the survival stance of each person in the system
Placating (Placator)
Blaming (Blamer)
Super-Reasonable (Computer)
Irrelevant (Distractor)
Congruent (Congruence)
Six Levels of Experience
Iceberg Model
For symptomatic behavior, describe:
Behavior
Coping
Feelings
Perceptions
Expectations
Yearnings
Self-Esteem or Self-Worth
Describe each person's level of self-worth.
Mind-Body Connection


Satir viewed the symptom as having a role in the family system.
Symptoms always have an emotional function in the family system, even if they are consciously and logically unwanted.
Why is this particular symptom manifesting in this particular family (or relationship)?
If the therapist can understand how the symptom makes emotional sense in the family dance, it will be easier to help the family find ways to interact successfully without the need for the symptom.


Along with assessing family roles, identify problematic family dynamics:
Power Struggles
These can be within the family and couple or with extended family members.
Parental Conflicts
These can involve parents disagreeing about how to parent and care for children.
Lack of Validation
The family openly expresses little emotional support or validation.
Lack of Intimacy
There is minimal sharing of significant personal information and one's emotional life.


Satir assessed each person's role in the family system to understand the function of the problem.
Possible roles include:
Martyr
Victim or Helpless One
Rescuer
Good Child or Parent
Bad Child or Parent


The family life chronology is a timeline that includes the major events in an individual's or family's life.
Births and deaths
Important family events (i.e., marriages, moves, tragedies, major illnesses, job loss)
Important historical events (i.e., wars, natural disasters, economic downturns)
This chronology gives both the therapist and the client a 'big picture' view of the context for the potential problem and provides clues as to what old wounds may be fueling the current problems, as well as what potential strengths and resources might exist.


Another area for assessment is the survival triad - the child, mother, and father - and the quality of the relationship between all three.
Satir asserted that it was in this primary triad that a child learns how to be human.
Is there an emotional bond between each parent and the child, or do the parents have significantly different levels of connection with the child?
Because the survival triad should serve as a nurturing system for the child, when the child is experiencing difficulty, the therapist considers how the nurturing function of these relationships can be improved.


One of Satir's last theoretical developments and central focus of contemporary work was the six levels of experience. Satir use these to help clients transform their feelings about feelings to make lasting change.
These levels are likened to an iceberg, with the behavior the only visible layer and the other five layers unseen beneath the surface.
At any moment, all six aspects are in play, but often we are not conscious of most of them.
The iceberg model is used to help individuals better understand their intrapsychic experience and for couples to understand how the levels of each person's experience resonates with the other.
Contemporary Satir practitioners help clients achieve intrapsychic congruence by identifying contradictions between these layers, such as taking actions one does not ultimately believe in.
The six layers of the iceberg:
Behavior
The behavior on the surface; the external manifestations of the person's inner world.
Coping
Defenses and Communication Stances:
Placating (Placator)
Blaming (Blamer)
Super-Reasonable (Computer)
Irrelevant (Distractor)
These come out in times of stress, and a person may use different stances in different relational contexts.
Feelings
Present feelings that are strongly past-based, using past events to interpret the present.
Contemporary practitioners also ask about a person's feelings about their feelings, which invites clients to relate to their feelings differently.
Perceptions
Beliefs, attitudes, and values that inform one's sense of self (most people form their perceptions when very young, and they are based on a limited view of reality).
Expectation
A strong belief about how life should go, how people should behave, and how one should perform (most people form their expectations when young, and they are often unrealistic and/or may not apply to a particular situation).
Yearnings
Universal longings to be loved, accepted, validated, and confirmed.
This level closely parallels the emphasis on secure attachment emotionally focused therapy.
Satir practitioners use the six levels of experience to assess the motivation behind problematic behaviors and interactions.
By understanding the yearnings as well as perceptions and expectations that fuel problematic behavior, coping, and feelings, therapists are able to help clients transform their feelings about their feelings (for example, being embarrassed about feeling angry) to more effectively meet the underlying longing for love and acceptance.


It is more useful to consider the specific aspects of the self that a client values and the aspects of which he or she is ashamed.
More recent research on self-esteem indicates that Self-Compassion self-compassion, or acceptance of one's strengths and weaknesses, is a better indicator of happiness than self-esteem, which can be artificially high.
People who overestimate their abilities and worth often have high self-esteem but significant problems in their interpersonal and work or school relationships because they have unrealistic expectations of 'what is due to them.'
The best indicator of health, self-compassion is one's ability to accept strengths and weaknesses are almost always equally harsh on themselves.
Conversely, those who are hard on themselves are almost always equally harsh on others, even if it is not verbalized.
As self-compassion and self-worth rise, people become more realistic and tolerant of their own and others' weaknesses while realistically assigning and assuming responsibility for their actions.


The mind-body connection considers how emotional issues may manifest in the body, either symbolically or functionally.
The role of nutrition and exercise is assessed.
Satir maintained that the way the body is used indicates the person's Communication Stances :
Congruent (Congruence) Communication and Self-Esteem or Self-Worth
Open and relaxed body postures
Placating (Placator)
Timid and reserved postures
Blaming (Blamer)
Pointing, angry, and stiff postures
Super-Reasonable (Computer)
Cold and distant postures
Irrelevant (Distractor)
Hyper and distracted


The goal of Satir's model is transformation:
To achieve optimal realization of a person's full potential.
This goal translates into two broad sets of practical goals for treatment planning:
Relational, family, or systemic goals
Individual goals


The heart of relational goals in Satir's approach is congruent communication:
The ability to communicate authentically while responding to the needs of both self and others.
The goal is to help the family develop ways for all members to communicate so that the system's homeostasis no longer needs the initial symptoms (problems) to maintain balance.


Increase congruent communication in relationships with spouse, parent, child, etc.
Change family rules and shoulds to general guidelines.


The overarching individual goal is consistent with other humanistic approaches:
To promote the self-actualization of all members of the system.



Therapists' use of self - being authentically who they are - is one of the most essential interventions.
By being authentic, therapists provide a role model for how to communicate congruently and also show the effects of increased self-actualization.
The use of the therapist's self in therapy, which may include self-disclosure, creates a safe relationship in which clients can practice communicating congruently without negative consequences and learn to tap into more authentic modes of expression.


The foundation for all other interventions, the ingredients of an interaction details the internal communication process and can be used to teach clients about internal and relational processes.
The ingredients questions are used to help people between understand their interactions with others and can be used with individuals, couples, or families.
When a client shares a troubling interaction with another, the therapists uses the following seven questions to walk the client through the 'ingredients of an interaction.'
What do I HEAR and SEE?
The therapist prompts clients to describe behaviorally what happened without adding interpretations.
This is similar to ' videotalk ' in Solution-Focused Therapy.
What MEANINGS do I make of what I hear and see?
After obtaining a clear, behavioral description, the therapist facilitates a discussion of how the clients interpreted these behaviors.
Meanings often connect back to past experiences.
What FEELINGS do I have about the meanings I make?
The therapist helps clients identify specific feelings about the meanings and interpretations.
Therapists use 'facilitation of emotional expression' techniques.
What FEELINGS do I have ABOUT these FEELINGS?
The therapist asks clients about whether they can accept and tolerate the feelings.
The more congruence a person is, the more accepting they are of various feelings.
If a person is not accepting, survival stances will be triggered (e.g., congruent: "I don't like these feelings, but I know that they are natural."; incongruent: "I don't like these feelings and need my child to do what I say so that I don't have such feelings anymore.")
Subsequent interventions target this level of feeling, not the emotions attached to the interpretation.
What DEFENSES do I use?
When people use incongruent communication, they respond in the interaction using defense mechanisms such as projection, denial, ignoring, or one of the Communication Stances.
What RULES FOR COMMENTING do I use?
Each person's family of origin and early significant others impart rules for commenting on interpersonal interactions that may limit self-worth, restrict choices, and determine what actions are 'allowed' and 'appropriate.'
Most of these rules are unspoken and brought into future relationships without reflection on whether they are appropriate or useful.
These rules are transformed using 'softening techniques'
What is my RESPONSE in the situation?
How does the client respond behaviorally and verbally?
Incongruent and problematic responses are targeted for change.


Satir therapists work with clients to help them express difficult-to-articulate emotions related to the presenting problem.
If the clients complain about family members or a difficult life situation, experiential therapists listen closely for the emotions, expressed or unexpressed, that are related to the problem circumstance.
They listen not just for the surface emotions, but also for deeper levels of emotion and use questions and empathetic reflections to focus clients on those deeper emotions.


If a client tells a story without identifying their emotions directly:
"As I listen to you explain what happened to you during that argument, I am getting a sense that you were feeling [name the emotion]. Does that sound right?"
"That sounds like a very difficult situation. Can you share some of the emotions you have been expeirencing as you go through this?"
If a client does identify emotions, the therapy can help explore them with questions such as:
"You say you were feeling [emotion]. I am wondering if part of you is also feeling [name another emotion that client seems to be experiencing]."
"Can you say more about what feeling [name emotion] feels like for you."


Satir coached families in softening rigid family rules by changing them to guidelines.
For example, rather than saying "I should not get angry," a client or family was encouraged to revise the limiting rule to "What I am angry, I will express my anger in a way that is respectful to others and myself."
Satir encouraged families to have as few rules as possible and to be flexible, adapting them for each context and as children's developmental needs change.


Coaching clients in how to have authentic, congruent communication in session, involves the ' Ingredients of an Interaction ' combined with specific communication coaching strategies.
When coaching communication, Satir had clients turn their chairs toward one another and gave the clients prompts, such as, "Tell your partner how you feel about what happened on Saturday night."
If the client was able to congruently address their partner about this, Satir then prompted the partner to respond in kind, continuing this process until the problem was resolved.
When a person had trouble communicating congruently and reverted to a survival stance, Satir interrupted the conversation and suggested how to rephrase the statement or how to make the client's nonverbal communication more congruent (e.g., "Now, can you say that starting the statement with 'I' instead of 'you'?" or "Can you show me the emotion you say you are feeling when you speak to your wife?")
The ' Ingredients of an Interaction ' technique was used to help coach clients through what they heard and saw, how they interpreted and felt about it, and the feelings about feelings and family-of-origin rules for communicating about what happened.


Family Sculpting, which is done either with the family or in a group setting.
Sculpting involves putting family members in physical positions that represent how the 'sculptor' sees each person's role in the family.
Either the therapist or the client may direct the sculpting.
If family members are directing the sculpting, each person in the family is given the opportunity to sculpt the family as they see it.
Sometimes the sculptor assigns each family member to say a line that represents how they may be feeling, thinking, or viewing the situation.
Usually, however, the essence of this intervention is to give a nonverbal, symbolic depiction of the family process from each person's perspective.
Sculpting is a highly effective nonverbal confrontation that bypasses cognitive defenses.
Through the sculpting process, a person is able to literally see how they are contributing to the problematic family process far more quickly than when the same information is provided with words.
When all family members are sculpting, it is generally best to let all family members sculpt how they see the family before allowing discussion of one another's sculpting.
Therapists encourage family members to respect each person's subjective experience as illustrated in the sculpting and to use the experience to deepen their understanding of one another.


Satir used touch in therapy to initially connect with clients and to encourage and reassure them when they were practicing new ways of communicating.
In this way, she underscored emotional context and provided palpable support.
She also used touch with children to help teach alternatives to violent behavior and to model for parents how to manage difficult children.
In today's practicing environments, touching is generally discouraged because it can easily be misinterpreted as sexual harassment or may make a client feel uncomfortable.
Therapists need to carefully consider the legal and ethical issues of using touch.
Touch may be appropriate in certain practice and cultural contexts.
At minimum, therapists can learn from Satir the importance of coaching clients in touching each other - their children and spouses - in more loving and helpful ways.
For example, rather than using a demonstration, therapists can guide a parent on how to hold children who are having a tantrum.



A form of psychodrama, the Family Reconstruction is used to allow clients to explore unresolved family issues and life events in the safety of the group setting.
The client, who is called the ' Star ,' first identifies key events in their life chronology and significant sources of influence. The Star then picks people from the group to reenact pivotal life experiences and relationships. The therapist facilitates the reenactment with the following three goals in mind:
Identifying the roots of old learning and their role in the present.
Developing a more realistic picture of the client's parents.
Discovering unique strengths and potentials.


A group activity similar to the Family Reconstruction, the Parts Party involves the client identifying group members to represent aspects of the self.
The person may have members enact generic characteristics (Martyr, Victim or Helpless One, savior) or use famous figures to represent different aspects of the self.
In this way, the therapist facilitates a process in which the client is better able to accept different aspects of the self and to identify the contexts in which these aspects have been and continue to be useful. The language of 'parts' can also be used to facilitate similar discussions and insights in individual, couples, and family therapy.



Satir's approach tracks pathologizing interpersonal patterns (PIPs) with a specific focus on the emotional level of the interaction and adds to it an understanding of the intrapsychic experiences within each person.
The Iceberg Model (Six Levels of Experience) helps therapists assess the internal PIPs that are part of the external PIP with others.
Survival stances often can be at the heart of PIP (Communication Stances)


In the Satir's model, wellness interpersonal patterns (WIPs) are conceptualized in terms of congruent communication (relationally) and self-worth (intrapersonally). These can take the form of listening compassionately/sharing vulnerability or acknowledging self/appreciating self.


When facilitating change, the therapist uses several forms of transformational interaction patters (TIPs).
Family Sculpting takes the form of having everyone first sculpt the PIP and then having each person sculpt their desired WIPs.
When working more intrapsychically, the Iceberg Model is used to identify both PIPs and WIPs as well, first identifying the negative inner monologue dialogue patterns (disapproving of self/disapproving of others) and then identifying alternatives (approving of self/approving of others).
Much of the family-of-origin work that characterize this approach involve healing interpersonal patterns (HIPs), especially the Family Reconstruction and Parts Party; this typically done by having another group member say what she always wished her parents would have said.




Describe the communication and validation patterns for all significant persons related to the client. For each person describe that:
Survival stance used when person feels invalidated.
Communication Stances


Describe the dynamics of each person's sense of self-worth and self-esteem, including contexts in which each has a greater or lesser sense of worth.
Describe dynamics of social location, such as cultural, gender, social class, or other diversity factors, that inform the evaluation of self.


Describe significant events, specifically those that may relate to sense of validation and worth, in family and/or relational life; list in chronological order.


Describe the following:
Power struggles and coalitions
Parental conflicts
Expression of intimacy/warmth between members
Salient family roles, including: martyr, victim, rescuer, good/bad parent or child, etc.
How the client or family's social location affects these dynamics, such as gender, ethnicity, socioeconomic class, sexual/gender orientation, etc.


Hypothesize homeostatic function of presenting problem:
How might the symptom serve to maintain connection, create independence/distance, establish influence, reestablish connection, or otherwise help create a sense of balance in the family?




Decrease use of Communication Stances in [key context where symptoms occur] to reduce depressed mood and anxiety
Use Ingredients of an Interaction technique to identify meanings, feelings, defenses, and rules for commenting in problem interactions.
Facilitate emotional expression related to depression and anxiety feelings.


Reduce shoulds and alter expectations for [specify area of life] to reduce sense of depression, hopelessness, and anxiety.
Use Ingredients of an Interaction technique to identify and alter shoulds and expectations related to depressive and anxious feelings.
Sculpt shoulds and expectations to increase awareness of emotions and history related to expectations.
Increase realistic perceptions, attitudes, and beliefs that inform the sense of self to reduce depression, hopelessness, and anxiety.
Soften family rules to reduce rigidity of beliefs and attitudes learned in family of origin.
Coach how to act from more realistic perceptions and attitudes.
Increase behaviors that more effectively fulfill client's yearnings for love and acceptance and reduce sense of depression and anxiety.
Use Ingredients of an Interaction intervention to identify underlying yearnings.
Role-Play new behaviors and forms of communication that help client fulfill yearnings for love and acceptance.


Increase daily experience of self-worth and ability to express and relate from authentic self in all areas of life to reduce depression and increase sense of wellness.
Sculpt from old versus new self to experientially understand the difference.
Coach to practice making decisions from authentic self.
Increase Congruent (Congruence) in work/school/extended family relations to reduce conflict and increase sense of wellness.
Sculpt key relationships from survival stance versus congruent stance to experience the difference.
Role-Play to practice communicating with others from congruent position.


Develop working therapeutic relationships.
Make contact with each client's authentic self using empathy and therapeutic presence.
Assess individual, systemic, and broader cultural dynamics.
Assess each individual's level of functioning by noting Communication Stances, Six Levels of Experience, related to the problem areas, and sense of self-worth.
Assess relational functioning by identifying relational dynamics, family roles, Survival Triad, and Family Life Chronology.
Identify referrals, crisis issues, collateral contacts, and other client needs.
Crisis assessment intervention (s):
Address crisis issues such as psychological abuse, intimate partner violence, hidden affairs, self-harm, suicidal ideation, substance use, etc.
Referral (s):
Connect client with resources in client's family and community that could be supportive
Make collateral contacts as needed.
